postTitle:
"Divorce is a passport to Hell."

St. Padre Pio
text:
Dominic Santos It is simply because divorce has more negative consequences than positive ones brother. Here are some recent findings from various studies that highlight the negative effects of divorce:

**On Children:**
- A study published in Social Indicators Research found that parental divorce and temporary separation can have significant negative effects on children's cognitive abilities and psychological well-being⁷.
- Another study published in BMC Public Health found that parental separation is associated with mental health problems in adolescence⁸.
- A report in Psychology Today noted that parental divorce is associated with significant risks for children and adolescents, including substance abuse, mental and physical health problems, and poor educational outcomes[^10^].

**On Adults:**
- A study in Frontiers in Psychology found that the mental and physical health of recent divorcees was worse than that of the background population and that higher levels of conflict predicted worse mental health³.
- Another study found that women's median income for the year of their separation or divorce dropped by about 30%, whereas men's median income decreased by only 6%⁹.

**On Society:**
- A study published in Frontiers in Psychology found that divorcees report poorer physical and mental health and more symptoms of stress, anxiety, depression, and social isolation than the general population¹.
- A report published by IDOSR noted that divorce damages society as it consumes social and human capital and diminishes children's future competence in all five of society's major tasks or institutions: family, school, religion, marketplace, and government².

**On Economy:**
- A report in Forbes noted that the average cost of a divorce is $15,000 per person and can increase to $100,000 for a more complicated situation, such as a custody dispute¹¹.
- A study published in SpringerLink found that women are economically disadvantaged following a divorce. Men tend to lose little or no income after a divorce, while the financial losses for women can be substantial⁵.

These findings suggest that divorce can have more negative effects than positive ones on children, adults, society, and the economy. It's also worth noting that there are many factors that can mitigate these effects, such as the quality of the relationship between the divorced parents, the level of conflict during the divorce, and the support systems available to the individuals involved.

Sources:
(1) The Causal Effects of Parental Divorce and Parental Temporary .... https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11205-020-02428-2.
(2) Parental separation, negative life events and mental health problems in .... https://bmcpublichealth.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12889-023-17307-x.
(3) The Impact of Divorce on Children | Psychology Today. https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/21st-century-childhood/202208/the-impact-divorce-children.
(4) Measuring broken hearts: divorce has negative effects on physical and .... https://www.frontiersin.org/news/2020/11/30/frontiers-psychology-mental-health-effects-divorce-men-women.
(5) Economic Consequences of Divorce and Separation - JustFacts. https://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/rp-pr/fl-lf/divorce/jf-pf/ecds-cfds.html.
(6) When Love Hurts – Mental and Physical Health Among Recently Divorced Danes. https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/psychology/articles/10.3389/fpsyg.2020.578083/full.
(7) The Effect of Divorce on the Society Yıldırım, D. S. and ... - IDOSR. https://idosr.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/IDOSR-JBESS-51-59-63-2020.-P7.pdf.
(8) The Financial Impact Of Divorce - Forbes. https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbesfinancecouncil/2022/10/20/the-financial-impact-of-divorce/.
(9) Economic Consequences of Divorce: A Review | SpringerLink. https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-030-44575-1_2.
(10) The Effects of Divorce on America | The Heritage Foundation. https://www.heritage.org/marriage-and-family/report/the-effects-divorce-america.
(11) Do the Privileged Always Win? Economic Consequences of Divorce by .... https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11205-021-02733-4.
(12) The Effects of Divorce on Children: A Parent's Guide. https://www.survivedivorce.com/divorce-effects-children.

text:
The Catholic Church was never an instrument of Social Progress. It is a cult born of Iron Age Myths and superstition passed down through ancient books served to protect their own interest. I’m lucky to have been born in the 21st century, otherwise, I’d most likely be burned like many other men of science, Philosophy and great thinkers that they have tortured and killed.

 1. Socrates (469-399 BC) - An Athenian philosopher, Socrates was sentenced to death by consuming poison hemlock. He was charged with impiety (not believing in the gods of the state) and corrupting the youth of Athens through his philosophical methods, which challenged the conventional beliefs of the time.
 2. Giordano Bruno (1548-1600) - An Italian philosopher and astronomer, Bruno was burned at the stake by the Roman Inquisition for his views on the infinity of the universe and the existence of multiple worlds, challenging the Church’s theological doctrines.
 3. Galileo Galilei (1564-1642) - Tried by the Inquisition in 1633 for supporting Copernican heliocentrism, contrary to the Church’s teaching of geocentrism. Galileo was forced to recant and lived under house arrest for the remainder of his life.
 4. Jan Hus (c. 1369-1415) - A Czech priest, philosopher, and early church reformer, burned at the stake for his criticisms of the Church’s leadership and corruption, deemed heretical by the Catholic Church.
 5. Michael Servetus (1511-1553) - Opposed by both Catholic and Protestant authorities, he was executed in Calvin’s Geneva for denying the Trinity and other doctrinal disagreements, after escaping Catholic territories.
 6. William Tyndale (c. 1494-1536) - Executed for heresy after translating the Bible into English, challenging the Church’s authority. His execution was backed by the English crown and the Catholic Church.
 7. Lucilio Vanini (1585-1619) - An Italian philosopher and free thinker, charged with atheism and blasphemy, and burned at the stake by the Catholic Church.
 8. Etienne Dolet (1509-1546) - A French scholar and printer, executed for atheism and blasphemy, including critical writings about the Bible and the Church.
 9. Cesare Cremonini (1550-1631) - Faced opposition from the Church for rejecting Aristotelian philosophy endorsed by the Church and denying the immortality of the soul.
 10. Jerome of Prague (1379-1416) - A close associate of Jan Hus, burned at the stake for heresy at the Council of Constance due to his teachings and reforms.
 11. Bruno Bauer (1809-1882) - His critical examinations of Christian origins and biblical criticisms led to opposition from the Catholic establishment, though more directly from the Protestant Church.
 12. Hypatia (c. 360-415 AD) - A mathematician and philosopher in Alexandria, murdered by a Christian mob due to her influence, pagan beliefs, and involvement in local politics, which conflicted with the religious upheaval of the time.

postTitle:
"Divorce is a passport to Hell."

St. Padre Pio
text:
Derick Tan 8. Teenagers whose parents divorce are more likely to experience mental health issues.
(Verywell Family)

There is no doubt that divorce affects children’s health. Children of divorce are more likely to have mental health issues, physical health problems, and behavioral problems. There are a number of divorced parent statistics that uphold this observation. In fact, teenagers with divorced parents are a lot more likely to experience mental health problems that require medication, counseling, or both. 

According to research published in the Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry, teenagers with divorced parents are about three times as likely to require counseling over the course of a year.

Overall, kids that come from broken homes tend to experience more speech issues, as well as headaches, asthma, illnesses, and injuries.

9. Therapists indicate that some children of divorced parents are likely to develop positive personality traits.
(GoodTherapy)

Not all is bleak, though. Some broken family statistics share the finding that children who grew up in single parent households due to a divorce have developed substantial resilience due to situations where they needed to cope with challenging emotional experiences. Moreover, owing to these activities, they have increased their understanding of complex interpersonal interactions and have become more empathetic as a result. 

Long-Term Effects of a Divorce on Children
Studies have shown that children of divorced parents are more likely to experience behavioral problems, academic difficulties, and mental health issues. They are also at greater risk of developing unhealthy relationships themselves. While no one deserves to live in an unhappy home, and there are undoubtedly positive effects of divorce on children, statistics don’t leave much room for optimism. 

Here’s what the figures say:

10. 70% of prison inmates incarcerated for long-term sentences grew up in broken homes, family separation statistics reveal.
(US Department of Justice)

More than two thirds of prison inmates who are incarcerated on a long-term basis due to more serious crimes are children born and raised in broken homes. Research suggests that children of divorced parents are more likely to become juvenile offenders. 

One reason for this is that divorce often disrupts the family structure and creates an environment of chaos and conflict. In turn, feelings of insecurity and isolation can surface, potentially leading to delinquent behavior. Additionally, children of divorce often have difficulty developing a sense of self-worth and may seek peer approval through criminal activity. 

While not all children of divorce will become juvenile offenders, it is important to be aware of the risks so that appropriate interventions can be put in place. With the right support, children of divorce can overcome the challenges they face and lead healthy, productive lives. 
11. Children are at a greater risk of living in poverty if their parents get a divorce.
(MDRC)

This is one of those children of divorced parents statistics that may not come as a surprise when you consider that getting a divorce can often mean that households have to make ends meet on a single income. Even with alimony and child support, the economic security of single-parent families rarely equals that of two-parent families. 

In line with this, children of divorced parents are five times more likely to end up living in poverty than children who still live with both of their parents. 

12. Children with divorced parents are twice as likely to drop out of high school.
(National Library of Medicine)

There are also some interesting children of divorce statistics relating to the effects of divorce on teenagers’ academic achievements. Figures indicate that kids with divorced parents are twice as likely to end up dropping out of high school compared to their peers who live with both biological parents. Moreover, the GPA of high school students from intact, nuclear families is 11% higher than that of kids from divorced families.

So, if you’re going through a divorce, you likely need to pay extra attention to your child’s performance in school. Talking to their teacher to explain the situation at home and presenting a unified front with your ex-partner when it comes to education are some of the steps you can take.

13. There is a link between divorce and a child’s academic performance.
(Marripedia)

Among all child and divorce facts, you will see that there are a lot of statistics on broken families that relate to a child’s academic performance. Earlier, we mentioned that teenagers are more likely to drop out of high school when their parents get divorced. This is not simply an expression of teenagers’ rebellious spirit, as can often happen because teenagers drop out of school so they can get a job and help their families pay for rent and food.

Aside from this, children who were young when their parents separated are twice as likely to quit school later in life and have a fear of professional commitment, thus holding low-paying jobs. What’s more, children who have been through a number of different divorces with their parents usually have lower grades when compared with children who have not experienced divorce in their home life.

postTitle:
"Divorce is a passport to Hell."

St. Padre Pio
text:
Derick Tan 3. According to statistics on children of divorce, roughly half of all children will see their parents’ marriage break up.
(CDC)

Children, like parents, are more likely to benefit from a divorce that will be transformed into two stable homes than they would be in the same household with dissatisfied parents.

On occasions when divorce is imminent, it is the best option for families with kids who have experienced domestic violence, abuse, or other negative behavioral patterns. Even when there are no instances of destructive conduct within the family, when going through a divorce, it’s paramount to pay attention to children’s needs and consult mediators and psychologists for help during that difficult time. 

About 50% of all American children will witness the end of their parents’ marriage. Of these children, slightly fewer than half will then go on to see their parents’ second marriage break up, and one in every 10 children who have divorced parents will then see the break up of three or more parental marriages. 

4. 21% of children are being raised without their fathers in America. 
(Census Bureau)

Children of divorce statistics show that it is usually the father who is absent from a child’s life, leading to the number of children living only with custodial mothers doubling in the past 50 years. These statistics on broken homes show that around 21% of American kids are growing up without a father.

The number of children living solely with their father has increased more than fourfold. This is due to a higher percentage of fathers striving to take on parenting roles that had previously been reserved for women. From 0.8 million children in 1968, which represented a mere 1%, the number grew to 3.3 million, or 4.5%. 

Divorced mothers of small children and those with adult children are also significantly more likely than fathers to balance work and family obligations well, so living with just the mother is still significantly more common than living only with the father.

Psychological and Physical Effects of Divorce on a Child
When it comes to the effects of divorce on children, statistics show that kids of parents who have split are more likely to experience health problems, including insomnia, stomachaches, and headaches. They are also more likely to encounter psychological issues, engaging in risky behaviors, such as smoking, drinking, and drug abuse, to alleviate the anxiety they might be experiencing.

Let’s take a closer look at the stats:

5. Children are more likely to experience behavioral issues if parents divorce when the child is between the ages of seven and 14.
(Marripedia)

Parents who continuously argue, even after the divorce proceedings, tend to show less affection, less attentiveness, and a greater penchant for disciplining their children. This kind of approach leaves kids feeling emotionally insecure.

As a result, kids are more likely to experience their social surroundings as chaotic, which further separates them from their peers who are growing up in stable homes. As a matter of fact, the majority of children who engage in fighting and theft come from broken homes. 

According to research carried out at the University College London, children are more likely to experience behavioral and emotional problems if their parents divorce when the child is between the ages of seven and 14. As children of divorce statistics reveal, there is a 16% increase in behavioral and emotional problems in this age bracket when compared to other ages.

6. Children with divorced parents are twice as likely to attempt suicide. 
(Science Daily)

The fact that suicidal thoughts are considerably more widespread among minors from broken homes is one of the most worrying effects of divorce on children. Now, this does not mean that you should stay with someone you no longer love because of an increased risk of suicide for your children. What it does mean, though, is that you need to account for the risk and take additional notice of your child’s behavior if you observe any changes, however slight they may be. 

It can be beneficial for children of divorce to see a therapist during this exasperating period to help them understand the situation and talk to someone who is not directly involved in the marriage breakdown. 

7. Children with divorced parents are four times as likely to have trouble fitting in.
(City University of New York)

Among children of divorce statistics is one indicating that children from broken homes tend to have more difficulty interacting with their peers. It shows that growing up with divorced parents means that they are four times more likely to experience problems with their friends and peers than children from intact families.

postTitle:

St. Padre Pio
text:
Derick Tan Statistics About Divorce and Children
There is no doubt that divorce is difficult for everyone involved, but children, in particular, might struggle the most. While divorce may make sense to couples, it can confuse the children. Most of the time, their needs are not met, and they cannot cope with the circumstances healthily.

1. Children experiencing a family break-up in early adolescence are more likely to have problems.
Children whose parents divorced in late childhood and early adolescence, between the ages of 7 and 14, had a 16% increase in emotional problems and an 8% increase in behavioral disorders in the short term.

2. Children of divorced parents are more likely to live in poverty.
Divorce causes family instability for an increasing number of children worldwide. Risk rises typically by a factor of 1.5 to 2. Children of divorced or separated parents are more likely to engage in risky activities, live in poverty, and experience family instability.

3. Divorce causes poor academic performance in children.
According to a study, children of divorced parents had an 8% lower probability of completing high school, a 12% lower likelihood of attending college, and an 11% lower chance of completing college.

Bottom Line
Divorce statistics can be cold, but it is helpful in putting things into perspective. At the very least, in knowing what can happen in a divorce and how it might affect the people you love, you can prepare yourself for what is to come.

postTitle:
"Divorce is a passport to Hell."

St. Padre Pio
text:
Derick Tan Divorce is a deadly killer!

by Atty. Jemy Gatdula

Pardon the quite unsubtle clickbait title. It is, to be clear, not meant to disrespect or make light of anybody’s circumstance. But two things: this article’s focus is on divorce specifically (and not of couples contemplating it). But also, it describes really how strongly some people feel about the matter.

Let’s face it: divorce signifies failure.

It’s hardly a thing to be celebrated.

Nobody gets married, in fact nobody grows up, hoping to get divorced. Something went wrong and in an array of difficult choices, divorce happens to be one of them. But it’s far from the best solution.

Divorce’s worst victims, as study upon study will show, are children.

Divorce “is catastrophic for children.” And it “is destructive to both boys and girls, but each sex suffers differently. Girls who grow up deprived of their father are more likely to become depressed, more likely to self-harm, and more likely to be promiscuous. But they still have their mothers, with whom they clearly identify. Boys do not have a comparable identification and thus suffer more from father absence. They also tend to act out in a manner that’s harmful to others, which girls typically do not.” (Suzanne Venker, “Missing fathers and America’s broken boys,” February 2018)

The US today is notorious for school shootings. But what mainstream media (mostly liberal) refuse to report is that most, if not all of the shooters were bereft of fathers, “whether due to divorce, death, or imprisonment” as Susan Goldberg points out (“When Will We Have the Guts to Link Fatherlessness to School Shootings?” February 2018).

Then there’s this: “72% of adolescent murderers grew up without fathers; the same for 60% of all rapists. 70% of juveniles in state institutions grew up in single- or no-parent situations. The number of single-parent households is a good predictor of violent crime in a community, while poverty rate is not.” (Terry Brennan, cofounder, Leading Women for Shared Parenting)

And contrary to what others say that the negative effects on children of divorced parents are merely short-term, Amy Desai (of Focus on the Family) reports:

“Psychologist Judith Wallerstein followed a group of children of divorce from the 1970s into the 1990s. Interviewing them at 18 months and then 5, 10, 15, and 25 years after the divorce, she expected to find that they had bounced back. But what she found was dismaying: Even 25 years after the divorce, these children continued to experience substantial expectations of failure, fear of loss, fear of change and fear of conflict. Twenty-five years!

The children in Wallerstein’s study were especially challenged when they began to form their own romantic relationships. As Wallerstein explains, “Contrary to what we have long thought, the major impact of divorce does not occur during childhood or adolescence. Rather, it rises in adulthood as serious romantic relationships move center stage …”

Other researchers confirm Wallerstein’s findings. Specifically, compared to kids from intact homes, children who experienced their parents’ divorce view premarital sex and cohabitation more favorably. This is disturbing news given that cohabiting couples have more breakups, greater risk of domestic violence and are more likely to experience divorce.”

Therapist Steven Earll points out, “Children never get over divorce. It is a great loss that is in their lives forever. It is like a grief that is never over. All special events, such as holidays, plays, sports, graduations, marriages, births of children, etc., bring up the loss created by divorce as well as the family relationship conflicts that result from the ‘extended family’ celebrating any event.”

In fact, Dr. Wallerstein explodes another myth, “that if the parents are happier the children will be happier, too.” So the argument goes: divorce frees children from living in an unhappy home. Not true.

“Indeed, many adults who are trapped in very unhappy marriages would be surprised to learn that their children are relatively content. They don’t care if mom and dad sleep in different beds as long as the family is together.” (see Brent Barlow, Brigham Young University, “Marriage Crossroads: Why Divorce Is Often Not The Best Option,” 2003)

Considering the stakes, we must avoid what Tim Wu calls the “tyranny of convenience,” which “fails to acknowledge that difficulty is a constitutive feature of human experience.”

Indeed, seeing their parents persevere in very difficult situations is perhaps one of the greatest things that can be given to children.

Finally, it’s quite tiresome hearing people parrot the line that to go against divorce is a step back to the dark ages. Most anthropological studies agree that human sexual development (from pre-humans to humans) went roughly by this sequence:

Group sex free for all => then temporary pairings => then longer termed “open” pairings => then marriage but with divorce => then (with the coming of Christianity) absolute permanent marriage.

Going by this chronology, to go with divorce is actually a regression.

Perhaps someone should tell that to Congress.

______________________

Atty. Jemy Gatdula is a Senior Fellow of the Philippine Council for Foreign Relations and a Philippine Judicial Academy law lecturer for constitutional philosophy and jurisprudence.

Eto po ang ticket to hell.

 1. Socrates (469-399 BC) - An Athenian philosopher, Socrates was sentenced to death by consuming poison hemlock. He was charged with impiety (not believing in the gods of the state) and corrupting the youth of Athens through his philosophical methods, which challenged the conventional beliefs of the time.
 2. Giordano Bruno (1548-1600) - An Italian philosopher and astronomer, Bruno was burned at the stake by the Roman Inquisition for his views on the infinity of the universe and the existence of multiple worlds, challenging the Church’s theological doctrines.
 3. Galileo Galilei (1564-1642) - Tried by the Inquisition in 1633 for supporting Copernican heliocentrism, contrary to the Church’s teaching of geocentrism. Galileo was forced to recant and lived under house arrest for the remainder of his life.
 4. Jan Hus (c. 1369-1415) - A Czech priest, philosopher, and early church reformer, burned at the stake for his criticisms of the Church’s leadership and corruption, deemed heretical by the Catholic Church.
 5. Michael Servetus (1511-1553) - Opposed by both Catholic and Protestant authorities, he was executed in Calvin’s Geneva for denying the Trinity and other doctrinal disagreements, after escaping Catholic territories.
 6. William Tyndale (c. 1494-1536) - Executed for heresy after translating the Bible into English, challenging the Church’s authority. His execution was backed by the English crown and the Catholic Church.
 7. Lucilio Vanini (1585-1619) - An Italian philosopher and free thinker, charged with atheism and blasphemy, and burned at the stake by the Catholic Church.
 8. Etienne Dolet (1509-1546) - A French scholar and printer, executed for atheism and blasphemy, including critical writings about the Bible and the Church.
 9. Cesare Cremonini (1550-1631) - Faced opposition from the Church for rejecting Aristotelian philosophy endorsed by the Church and denying the immortality of the soul.
 10. Jerome of Prague (1379-1416) - A close associate of Jan Hus, burned at the stake for heresy at the Council of Constance due to his teachings and reforms.
 11. Bruno Bauer (1809-1882) - His critical examinations of Christian origins and biblical criticisms led to opposition from the Catholic establishment, though more directly from the Protestant Church.
 12. Hypatia (c. 360-415 AD) - A mathematician and philosopher in Alexandria, murdered by a Christian mob due to her influence, pagan beliefs, and involvement in local politics, which conflicted with the religious upheaval of the time.

Kamusta po ang libo-libong ipinapatay ng Church n’yo to protect your Iron Age beliefs?

 1. Medieval Inquisition (1184-1230s)
 • Estimated Deaths/Tortures: Thousands executed; specific numbers for tortures are not well-documented.
 • Description: Initiated to counter the Cathar and Waldensian heresies in Southern France and Northern Italy, involving severe interrogation techniques and executions, primarily by burning at the stake.
 2. Spanish Inquisition (1478-1834)
 • Estimated Deaths/Tortures: Approximately 150,000 prosecuted, with 2,000 to 5,000 executed.
 • Description: Established by the Spanish monarchy to maintain Catholic orthodoxy among converted Jews and Muslims, notorious for its harsh torture methods and public burnings.
 3. Portuguese Inquisition (1536-1821)
 • Estimated Deaths/Tortures: Around 40,000 tried, with several hundred executed.
 • Description: Aimed at ensuring the orthodoxy of converts from Judaism and Islam, using similar torturous interrogation methods to the Spanish Inquisition to extract confessions and enforce religious conformity.

St. Padre Pio
text:
Also, kamusta na ba mga sexual scandals ng mga ka-baro ninyo, may nakulong na po ba?

 1. The Pennsylvania Grand Jury Report: A 2018 report detailing widespread sexual abuse by clergy in Pennsylvania, USA.
 • Summary: This extensive report, released in 2018, documented the sexual abuse of over 1,000 child victims by more than 300 priests over a span of seven decades. The report provided harrowing details of the abuse, cover-ups by Church officials, and the systemic nature of the crimes. It highlighted the failure of Church leaders to report the abuse to law enforcement and their efforts to shield perpetrators from accountability.
 • Detailed Summary of Abuses:
 • Victims ranged from pre-pubescent to teenage years.
 • Abuses included rape, molestation, and other forms of sexual assault.
 • Church officials often reassigned accused priests to different parishes rather than removing them from ministry.
 • Efforts to intimidate or silence victims and their families were documented.
 • A pervasive culture of secrecy and protection of the Church’s reputation over the welfare of the victims was evident.
 2. The McCarrick Report: A 2020 Vatican report on the misconduct of former Cardinal Theodore McCarrick.
 • Summary: The McCarrick Report, released by the Vatican in 2020, detailed the rise and fall of former Cardinal Theodore McCarrick, who was found to have engaged in decades of sexual misconduct, including with minors and young seminarians. The report examined how McCarrick was able to rise to high ranks within the Church despite allegations and rumors about his behavior.
 • Detailed Summary of Abuses:
 • McCarrick was accused of sexually abusing minors and young adult seminarians.
 • Instances of abuse included inappropriate touching, sharing beds, and coerced sexual acts.
 • The report revealed failures within the Church hierarchy, where warnings and accusations were ignored or inadequately investigated.
 • McCarrick’s influential status and fundraising abilities contributed to the reluctance to act on allegations.
 • The report highlighted the need for improved processes for handling accusations and greater transparency within the Church.
 3. Vatileaks: Refers to the leaks of confidential Vatican documents in 2012 and 2015, revealing corruption and financial scandals within the Vatican.
 • Summary: The Vatileaks scandals involved the unauthorized release of confidential Vatican documents, which exposed corruption, financial mismanagement, and internal power struggles within the Vatican. The leaks were facilitated by individuals within the Vatican and brought to light issues that had long been suspected but not publicly documented.
 • Detailed Summary of Abuses:
 • Financial corruption, including misuse of Church funds and embezzlement.
 • Discrepancies in the handling of donations and charitable funds.
 • Evidence of favoritism and nepotism within Vatican appointments and operations.
 • Internal power struggles and conflicts among high-ranking officials.
 • Attempts to cover up financial irregularities and maintain a facade of transparency.
 4. The Sipe Report: Richard Sipe’s research and reports on sexual abuse within the Catholic Church.
 • Summary: Richard Sipe, a former priest and psychotherapist, conducted extensive research on the sexual behavior of Catholic clergy, focusing on the systemic issues contributing to the abuse crisis. His work exposed the prevalence of sexual abuse, the culture of secrecy, and the failures of Church leadership to address the problem effectively.
 • Detailed Summary of Abuses:
 • Sipe estimated that a significant percentage of priests had engaged in sexual misconduct, including abuse of minors.
 • His research highlighted the struggles with celibacy and how it contributed to unhealthy sexual behaviors.
 • Documentation of abuse cases where victims were silenced or intimidated.
 • Detailed accounts of the psychological impact on victims, emphasizing long-term trauma and the need for support.
 • Advocacy for systemic reforms, including greater transparency, accountability, and reconsideration of celibacy requirements for clergy.

postTitle:

St. Padre Pio
text:
Kaya siguro pababa nang pababa ang umaattend ng misa dahil marami sa mga pari ay masyadong abala sa pagpapasa ng "passport to hell" sermon kaysa sa pag-intindi sa tunay na kalagayan ng kanilang mga parokyano. Hindi ba nila napapansin na ang dami nang umaalis sa simbahan dahil sa kanilang sobrang pagiging judgmental?

Maraming Katoliko, Catholic lang by default, walang tunay na pag-unawa o malasakit. Ang dami rin sa kanila, sobrang judgmental at mahilig mang-condemn ng iba, kesyo makasalanan daw ang mga sumusuporta sa divorce, pero hindi naman nila naiintindihan ang hirap at pighati ng mga nasa abusive relationships. Mas gusto pa nilang magtago sa likod ng moralidad kuno habang pinapabayaan ang tunay na pangangailangan ng kapwa.

Maraming umaalis sa simbahan dahil sa toxic na kultura ng hypocrisy, judgment, at kawalan ng compassion. Sa halip na magpakita ng tunay na pagmamahal at malasakit, inuuna pa nila ang paghusga at pagpilit ng sarili nilang paniniwala sa iba. Paano mo naman aasahan na mananatili ang mga tao sa simbahan kung ganito ang kanilang nakikita at nararanasan?

At talaga namang "passport to hell" daw ang divorce? E paano naman yung mga asawa na araw-araw ay nasa impiyerno na sa mga abusadong relasyon? Sa tingin ko, mas impiyerno pa yata ang manatili sa isang relasyong puno ng pang-aabuso at takot. Imbes na makinig at tumulong, mas pinipili pa nilang manermon at magbigay ng "divine passport." Kaya naman, hindi nakakapagtakang unti-unti nang nawawala ang tiwala ng mga tao sa ganitong klaseng simbahan.

postTitle:
"Divorce is a passport to Hell."

St. Padre Pio
text:
"Hindi ko na kailangan pang basahin ang bill o makinig sa hearings para malaman na mali ang divorce," sabi ng isang sagrado katolikong sarado ang utak at ayaw pakinggan ang mga realidad ng lipunan, lalo na sa mga naghihirap. Pero sila pa itong malakas mangialam at ipilit ang relihiyon nila sa iba. Hypocrite much?

Helaria Legaspi, halimbawa, nagpakasal noong 15 taong gulang at nang matuklasan niyang may kalaguyo ang kanyang asawa, sinubukan niyang magpa-annul. Ngunit dahil sa sobrang mahal ng proseso at takot na maloko, napilitan siyang sumuko. "It was just too expensive for me to even dream of. There was no way that I could afford it, so I never went back," sabi ni Helaria. Maraming babae ang tulad niya, hindi makaalis sa kanilang abusadong relasyon dahil sa kawalan ng sapat na pera.

Ayon naman sa Gabriela Women’s Party, mula 2009 hanggang 2011, naitala nila ang 1,452 kaso ng karahasan sa loob ng kasal, na bumubuo ng 67% ng lahat ng kasong hawak nila tungkol sa karahasan laban sa kababaihan. Pinapakita nito na maraming babae ang nananatiling bihag ng kanilang mga abusadong asawa dahil walang divorce na maaring pagpilian.

Isang 2017 survey rin ang nagsasaad na isa sa apat na Pilipinang may edad 15 hanggang 49 ay nakaranas ng pisikal, emosyonal, o sekswal na pang-aabuso mula sa kanilang mga partner. Marami sa kanila ang hindi nagrereport ng abuso dahil sa takot, kawalan ng pera, at kawalan ng tiwala sa sistema ng hustisya. Dahil dito, nagiging normal na lang ang karahasan sa loob ng tahanan, at maraming kababaihan ang walang magawa kundi tiisin ito para sa kanilang mga anak.

Maria Santos, isang ina ng tatlong anak, ay nakaranas ng pisikal na pang-aabuso mula sa kanyang asawa. "Araw-araw, takot ako na baka saktan na naman ako. Pero wala akong magawa kasi wala akong trabaho at ayaw ko rin iwanan ang mga anak ko," sabi ni Maria. Gusto niyang magpa-annul pero hindi niya kaya ang gastos at proseso nito.

Lorna Cruz, isang domestic helper na umuwi mula sa ibang bansa, ay nakatagpo ng mas masahol pang sitwasyon. Nang bumalik siya sa Pilipinas, nalaman niyang pinagsasama-sama ng kanyang asawa ang kanyang sahod para sa kanyang mga bisyo at kalaguyo. "Kahit sa ibang bansa, wala akong kalayaan. Lahat ng pinaghirapan ko, napupunta lang sa kanya," sabi ni Lorna. Sinubukan niyang humingi ng tulong pero napakahirap makakuha ng suporta at tulong sa legal na proseso.

Kaya pababa nang pababa ang umaattend ng mga misa at religious services ng Katoliko dahil marami diyan ay paimbabaw lang ang pananampalataya at hindi makatao. Marami sa kanila, Catholic lang by default kasi iyon ang nakagisnan, walang tunay na pag-unawa o malasakit.

Ang dami rin sa kanila, sobrang judgmental at mahilig mang-condemn ng iba, kesyo makasalanan daw ang mga sumusuporta sa divorce, pero hindi naman nila naiintindihan ang hirap at pighati ng mga nasa abusive relationships. Mas gusto pa nilang magtago sa likod ng moralidad kuno habang pinapabayaan ang tunay na pangangailangan ng kapwa.

Sa totoo lang, maraming umaalis sa simbahan dahil sa toxic na kultura ng hypocrisy, judgment, at kawalan ng compassion. Sa halip na magpakita ng tunay na pagmamahal at malasakit, inuuna pa nila ang paghusga at pagpilit ng sarili nilang paniniwala sa iba. Paano mo naman aasahan na mananatili ang mga tao sa simbahan kung ganito ang kanilang nakikita at nararanasan?

By Pastor Ed Lapiz

Q - Eh Tito di po sabi ni God sa Bible, "I hate divorce"?

A - Yung divorce na tinutukoy sa Bible ay yung divorce na uso noon: One way, only in the favor of men. Noon kasi, pag ayaw na sa wife ng husband, sasabihin lang nya, "I divorce you." Tapos, divorced na. Free na ang lalake na mag-asawa ulit ng kahit sino, pero yung babae hinde. Tapos pag sawa na sya sa bagong wife, idi-divorce nya lang ulit basta. May nangdidivorce pa nga para lang mag-asawa at maenjoy ang ibang babae. Tapos ididivorce nya ulit at babalikan ang dating wife.

text:
Some religious peeps acknowledge reasons for annulment, while condemning abuse and infidelity.  Isn't infidelity a sin as well?  If marriage is a sacred covenant between spouses and God, why discourage divorce, especially for those escaping abuse?  If followers of god acknowledge annulment and adultery, abuse is a sin, why isn't annulment an option for adultery and abuse? The Bible says that God hates abuse, viewing it as sinful and unacceptable. Why emphasize rare grounds for annulment instead of acknowledging victims of abuse and maltreatment?  Surely God wouldn't want someone to endure such suffering. Many people suffer from all kinds of domestic abuse.  They are often too afraid to seek help, and some even resort to suicide. Yes, Suicide itself is considered a sin, yet they often focus on the act itself rather than the reasons behind it, such as the abuse that may have driven the person to that point.

And besides, why do you guys worry about children from divorced parents who can have shared custody and fulfill their responsibilities, yet not show the same concern for children of abusive households?  Shouldn't they be equally concerned about the environment these children grow up in?

postTitle:
"Divorce is a passport to Hell."

St. Padre Pio
text:
Kae Maderazo Divorce is a deadly killer!

by Atty. Jemy Gatdula

Pardon the quite unsubtle clickbait title. It is, to be clear, not meant to disrespect or make light of anybody’s circumstance. But two things: this article’s focus is on divorce specifically (and not of couples contemplating it). But also, it describes really how strongly some people feel about the matter.

Let’s face it: divorce signifies failure.

It’s hardly a thing to be celebrated.

Nobody gets married, in fact nobody grows up, hoping to get divorced. Something went wrong and in an array of difficult choices, divorce happens to be one of them. But it’s far from the best solution.

Divorce’s worst victims, as study upon study will show, are children.

Divorce “is catastrophic for children.” And it “is destructive to both boys and girls, but each sex suffers differently. Girls who grow up deprived of their father are more likely to become depressed, more likely to self-harm, and more likely to be promiscuous. But they still have their mothers, with whom they clearly identify. Boys do not have a comparable identification and thus suffer more from father absence. They also tend to act out in a manner that’s harmful to others, which girls typically do not.” (Suzanne Venker, “Missing fathers and America’s broken boys,” February 2018)

The US today is notorious for school shootings. But what mainstream media (mostly liberal) refuse to report is that most, if not all of the shooters were bereft of fathers, “whether due to divorce, death, or imprisonment” as Susan Goldberg points out (“When Will We Have the Guts to Link Fatherlessness to School Shootings?” February 2018).

Then there’s this: “72% of adolescent murderers grew up without fathers; the same for 60% of all rapists. 70% of juveniles in state institutions grew up in single- or no-parent situations. The number of single-parent households is a good predictor of violent crime in a community, while poverty rate is not.” (Terry Brennan, cofounder, Leading Women for Shared Parenting)

And contrary to what others say that the negative effects on children of divorced parents are merely short-term, Amy Desai (of Focus on the Family) reports:

“Psychologist Judith Wallerstein followed a group of children of divorce from the 1970s into the 1990s. Interviewing them at 18 months and then 5, 10, 15, and 25 years after the divorce, she expected to find that they had bounced back. But what she found was dismaying: Even 25 years after the divorce, these children continued to experience substantial expectations of failure, fear of loss, fear of change and fear of conflict. Twenty-five years!

The children in Wallerstein’s study were especially challenged when they began to form their own romantic relationships. As Wallerstein explains, “Contrary to what we have long thought, the major impact of divorce does not occur during childhood or adolescence. Rather, it rises in adulthood as serious romantic relationships move center stage …”

Other researchers confirm Wallerstein’s findings. Specifically, compared to kids from intact homes, children who experienced their parents’ divorce view premarital sex and cohabitation more favorably. This is disturbing news given that cohabiting couples have more breakups, greater risk of domestic violence and are more likely to experience divorce.”

Therapist Steven Earll points out, “Children never get over divorce. It is a great loss that is in their lives forever. It is like a grief that is never over. All special events, such as holidays, plays, sports, graduations, marriages, births of children, etc., bring up the loss created by divorce as well as the family relationship conflicts that result from the ‘extended family’ celebrating any event.”

In fact, Dr. Wallerstein explodes another myth, “that if the parents are happier the children will be happier, too.” So the argument goes: divorce frees children from living in an unhappy home. Not true.

“Indeed, many adults who are trapped in very unhappy marriages would be surprised to learn that their children are relatively content. They don’t care if mom and dad sleep in different beds as long as the family is together.” (see Brent Barlow, Brigham Young University, “Marriage Crossroads: Why Divorce Is Often Not The Best Option,” 2003)

Considering the stakes, we must avoid what Tim Wu calls the “tyranny of convenience,” which “fails to acknowledge that difficulty is a constitutive feature of human experience.”

Indeed, seeing their parents persevere in very difficult situations is perhaps one of the greatest things that can be given to children.

Finally, it’s quite tiresome hearing people parrot the line that to go against divorce is a step back to the dark ages. Most anthropological studies agree that human sexual development (from pre-humans to humans) went roughly by this sequence:

Group sex free for all => then temporary pairings => then longer termed “open” pairings => then marriage but with divorce => then (with the coming of Christianity) absolute permanent marriage.

Going by this chronology, to go with divorce is actually a regression.

Perhaps someone should tell that to Congress.

______________________

Atty. Jemy Gatdula is a Senior Fellow of the Philippine Council for Foreign Relations and a Philippine Judicial Academy law lecturer for constitutional philosophy and jurisprudence.

postTitle:

St. Padre Pio
text:
Kae Maderazo 3. According to statistics on children of divorce, roughly half of all children will see their parents’ marriage break up.
(CDC)

Children, like parents, are more likely to benefit from a divorce that will be transformed into two stable homes than they would be in the same household with dissatisfied parents.

On occasions when divorce is imminent, it is the best option for families with kids who have experienced domestic violence, abuse, or other negative behavioral patterns. Even when there are no instances of destructive conduct within the family, when going through a divorce, it’s paramount to pay attention to children’s needs and consult mediators and psychologists for help during that difficult time. 

About 50% of all American children will witness the end of their parents’ marriage. Of these children, slightly fewer than half will then go on to see their parents’ second marriage break up, and one in every 10 children who have divorced parents will then see the break up of three or more parental marriages. 

4. 21% of children are being raised without their fathers in America. 
(Census Bureau)

Children of divorce statistics show that it is usually the father who is absent from a child’s life, leading to the number of children living only with custodial mothers doubling in the past 50 years. These statistics on broken homes show that around 21% of American kids are growing up without a father.

The number of children living solely with their father has increased more than fourfold. This is due to a higher percentage of fathers striving to take on parenting roles that had previously been reserved for women. From 0.8 million children in 1968, which represented a mere 1%, the number grew to 3.3 million, or 4.5%. 

Divorced mothers of small children and those with adult children are also significantly more likely than fathers to balance work and family obligations well, so living with just the mother is still significantly more common than living only with the father.

Psychological and Physical Effects of Divorce on a Child
When it comes to the effects of divorce on children, statistics show that kids of parents who have split are more likely to experience health problems, including insomnia, stomachaches, and headaches. They are also more likely to encounter psychological issues, engaging in risky behaviors, such as smoking, drinking, and drug abuse, to alleviate the anxiety they might be experiencing.

Let’s take a closer look at the stats:

5. Children are more likely to experience behavioral issues if parents divorce when the child is between the ages of seven and 14.
(Marripedia)

Parents who continuously argue, even after the divorce proceedings, tend to show less affection, less attentiveness, and a greater penchant for disciplining their children. This kind of approach leaves kids feeling emotionally insecure.

As a result, kids are more likely to experience their social surroundings as chaotic, which further separates them from their peers who are growing up in stable homes. As a matter of fact, the majority of children who engage in fighting and theft come from broken homes. 

According to research carried out at the University College London, children are more likely to experience behavioral and emotional problems if their parents divorce when the child is between the ages of seven and 14. As children of divorce statistics reveal, there is a 16% increase in behavioral and emotional problems in this age bracket when compared to other ages.

6. Children with divorced parents are twice as likely to attempt suicide. 
(Science Daily)

The fact that suicidal thoughts are considerably more widespread among minors from broken homes is one of the most worrying effects of divorce on children. Now, this does not mean that you should stay with someone you no longer love because of an increased risk of suicide for your children. What it does mean, though, is that you need to account for the risk and take additional notice of your child’s behavior if you observe any changes, however slight they may be. 

It can be beneficial for children of divorce to see a therapist during this exasperating period to help them understand the situation and talk to someone who is not directly involved in the marriage breakdown. 

7. Children with divorced parents are four times as likely to have trouble fitting in.
(City University of New York)

Among children of divorce statistics is one indicating that children from broken homes tend to have more difficulty interacting with their peers. It shows that growing up with divorced parents means that they are four times more likely to experience problems with their friends and peers than children from intact families.

St. Padre Pio
text:
YES TO DIVORCE KA? Basaha sani para sa imoha ni.

 1. Ano ang annulment? 

Answer. Kapag "annuled" na ang isang couple, idinedeklara na walang bisa o "void" ang kasal nila from the start. In other words, walang totoong kasal na naganap sa kanila. Kaya, pwede silang mag-asawa ulit kasi hindi naman talaga sila totoong kasal simula't sapul. Walang marriage na binubuwag sa annulment kasi walang totoong marriage na naganap. 

PS. Ang "annulment" na pinag-uusapan ko rito ay CHURCH ANNULMENT at hindi CIVIL ANNULMENT.

2. Ano ang legal separation? 

Answer. Sa legal separation magkahiwalay ang couple pero hindi pwedeng mag-asawa ulit dahil "valid" ang marriage nila. Makoconsider na "adultery" kapag nakapagrelasyon sa iba. Isang MALAKING KASALANAN ang adultery na pwedeng magdala sa atin sa impyerno. 

3. Ano ang divorce? 

Answer. Sa divorce magkahiwalay ang couple at pwedeng magpakasal ulit kahit na "valid" ang marriage nila. 

Sabi ng Panginoong Hesus, "Ang pinagsama ng Diyos ay huwag paghiwalayin ng tao (MARK 10:9)." 

"Matthew 5:32"
 But I tell you that anyone who divorces his wife, except for sexual immorality, makes her the victim of adultery, and anyone who marries a divorced woman commits adultery.

"Matthew 19:6"
What therefore God has Joined together, let no man Separate."

"Malachi 2:16"
“Nasusuklam ako sa pagpapalayas at paghihiwalay ng mga mag-asawa,” sabi ni Yahweh, ang Diyos ng Israel. “

Di Sa nagpapakabanal Di ba poyding Ipaglaban ang Utos nang Dios kong di ka banal? Lahat tayu ay lilipas lang sa Mundo sa Dios din tayu haharap.

Kong imohang Na asawa or na bana grabi ka Badlongon og Di na Makaya  Likaye lang ,og Mupatay na ipa Preso Perte ka Basic rajod or mao nang naay
     legal separation ngano mo ado paman kag Divorce jod para Maka minyu kag Usab?? 
 Onsay ingon sa Matthew 5:32  Gani? Ang si kinsa mang Makig minyo sa taong Divorces kay Maka buhat og Mortal na sala na adultery.

Sa divorce, ginagawa na lang "temporary contract" ang marriage imbes na "lifetime commitment" ito. Nagiging CHEAP ang value ng marriage dahil mas dadami pa ang mga couple na magpapakasal kahit hindi pa handa. 

"Magpakasal na tayo. Total, pwede naman tayong magdivorce anytime kung gugustohin natin," malamang ito ang magiging usual reason sa pagpapakasal kung magiging legal ang divorce. 

4. Papano yung mga pamilyang sirang-sira na? 

Answer. Sa mga pamilyang sirang-sira na, meron namang annulment at legal separation. So, no need na ang divorce. 

Ipakulong nyo ang abusive partner. May VAWC law po tayo.

5. Diba pareho lang namang naghihiwalay ang couple sa annulment, legal separation, at divorce? 

Answer. Oo. Parehong naghihiwalay pero MAGKAIBA pa rin ang case at nature. 

Sa annulment hindi nasisira ang SANCTITY OF MARRIAGE kasi wala namang marriage na nangyari in the first place.

Sa legal separation naman, kahit na magkahiwalay ang mag-asawa, eh hindi naman pwedeng mag-asawa ulit kasi ADULTERY yun. Malaking kasalanan yun. Tsaka may chance pang magbalikan ang couple kung sakali. 

Sa divorce, sinisira nito ang SANCTITY OF MARRIAGE kasi kahit na valid ang kasal, ihinihiwalay pa rin ang couple at binibigyan sila ng karapatan na mag-asawa ulit which is ADULTERY. Divorce promotes adultery. Divorce promotes sin. Divorce promotes hell. 

In addition, mas lumalabo ang chance na ma save pa ang marriage kasi binigbiyan ng right na mag-asawa ulit sa iba. 

6. Mahal at matagal ang proseso ng annulment. Kaya, kailangan ilegalize ang divorce.

Answer. Yun pala e. Ang process pala ang problema. So, yun dapat ang i-fix. Dapat gumawa ng hakbang ang kongreso, together with the Church, para mas mapadali at maging affordable ang annulment process. So, di na kailangan pang ipush ang divorce. Kailangan lang ayusin ang annulment process sa bansa.

7. Hayaan na lang natin ang mga couple kung ano ang gusto nilang option. Wala kayong karapatan na manghimasok sa buhay nila. Tsaka, hindi naman lahat Katoliko. Hindi lahat naniniwala sa Bibliya.

Answer: Hindi natin pwedeng bigyan ng MALING OPTION ang tao. Maling option po ang divorce. Kagaya lang yan sa abortion at suicide. 

"Sanctity of Marriage" na po ang nakasalalay dito. Kaya dapat kaming mag-ingay against divorce. Kapag binibigyan natin ng karapatan ang tao na sirain ang "sanctity of marriage", binibigyan na rin natin siya ng karapatan na sirain ang pamilya. Kapag sira ang pamilya, sira rin ang lipunan.  Halimbawa Yung Anak Mo naka pangasawa nang mayaman tapos Papakasalan lang at titikman at  Gagamitin tapos eh divorces ikaw magulang matutuwa kaba sa DiVORCES na yan..   Lalo na Sigurado na ang Divorces na Yan ay napaka mahal kong Ma approved sino lang ang Makikinabang Ang Mayayaman.. eh Pag Na Approve Ang Divorce na yan maraming Mayayamang Abosado.Poydi kang Gamitin or ang anak mo  Para Tikman lang tapos eh de divorces na  Payag ka kaya mang yari yan sa anak or Kapamilya mo..!? isip isip din pag may time😌

St. Padre Pio
text:
Here are some non-Biblical, non-religious reasons why we are against the passage of the divorce bill:

EFFECTS OF DIVORCE ON CHILDREN

“Research has documented that parental divorce/separation is associated with an increased risk for child and adolescent adjustment problems, including academic difficulties (e.g., lower grades and school dropout), disruptive behaviors (e.g., conduct and substance use problems), and depressed mood”

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6313686/

EFFECTS OF DIVORCE ON WOMEN

After divorce, women experience disproportionate declines in household income (de Vaus et al. 2015; Smock 1994) and standard of living (Bianchi et al. 1999; Peterson 1996) as well as sharp increases in the risk of poverty (Smock and Manning 1999). Women may also face a higher risk of losing homeownership and “falling down the housing ladder” (Dewilde 2008). Women’s lower chances of repartnering (Wu and Schimmele 2005) and responsibilities as a single parent may further impede their path to economic recovery.

EFFECTS OF DIVORCE ON MEN

Individuals who are divorced or separated are more prone to health problems related to chronic stress (Chen et al., 2014). 

Divorced men are significantly more prone to depression, suicide, substance abuse and heart disease than married men.

https://www.liebertpub.com/doi/abs/10.1016/j.jomh.2012.09.002

Multivariate event history models show that after divorce, men experience an increased chance of becoming downwardly mobile, an increased chance of becoming unemployed, and an increased chance of becoming disabled. 

https://www.matthijskalmijn.nl/onewebmedia/Kalmijn%20-%20EJP%20-%20Divorce%20and%20mens%20employment%20histories.pdf

EFFECTS OF DIVORCE ON SOCIETY

Increasing crime rates and substance use, with associated societal and governmental costs (Waite and Gallagher 2000).

Increasing risk for school suspensions, “Persons in Need of Supervision” status, binge drinking, and marijuana use (Demuth and Brown 2004; Eckenrode, Mrcynyszyn, and Evans 2008; Osborne, Manning, and Stock 2007).

EFFECTS OF DIVORCE ON ECONOMY

Studies have attempted to estimate the financial cost of divorce to the United States, with most recent estimates reaching $33.3 billion per year, and with adolescent pregnancy costing at least $7 billion (Schramm 2003).

#NoToDivorce

postTitle:
"Divorce is a passport to Hell."

St. Padre Pio
text:
Vernian Don Martin DIVORCE, WHY NOT? 

People who say no to divorce are not imposing their beliefs. That's too obvious to need to be pointed out. What they're saying is that divorce is not for our common good. In fact, it will lead to disaster. It will hurt us more, hurt more children and women, destroy more families, weaken and make relationships and trust more difficult. 

The divorce issue is not just about "if you don't want divorce, then don't get one." Divorce poisons everything and so affects us all. It will make our morally decadent country worse. It will lead to more fatherless children, single moms, and angry, hateful, and suicidal teens. It will just empower and free your husband to enjoy more women in uncommitted relationships. Go research the facts. 

Children can recover easier when their father dies or is jailed. But it will be very difficult for them to recover if they know their divorced father is out there enjoying his free life with other women while they are suffering and experiencing economic difficulties. Thus, the argument on "abusive or nambabae na asawa" is amazing in its irrelevance. We have annulment, legal separation, and enhanced laws on violence committed against women and children. It is the duty of the woman to protect herself and her children from anyone who physically hurts them, even if it is her husband. If a husband is abusive or unfaithful, then jail him. By the way, many dysfunctional relationships today can be resolved by annulments since, truth be told, many marriages today are invalid for obvious reasons.

If two of the grounds for divorce are "abuse" and "unfaithfulness," and if that can be established before the court, then why not jail the perpetrator instead of granting divorce? If the compelling argument is to free the woman and children from the abuse, then the application of existing laws suffice, right? You might object in this way: "But if I jail my husband, who will support us?" But do you really think that if you divorce your husband, you can get a better one? The odds of not getting a new male partner to financially support you and your children after divorce and separation are, in fact, almost the same. Here in the Philippines, for cultural and economic reasons, single moms find it difficult to get financial support from the father of their kids. There is no reason to think that it will improve if we legalize divorce. But there are many reasons to believe it will worsen especially for poor families.

There are practical ways we can do to help problematic families if we are really serious about it. And the truth is, we haven't really gotten serious about it. On the other hand, legalizing divorce is both like and worse than legalizing marijuana or gun ownership. It's not simply giving an option to those who need it while the rest go on with their lives unharmed. No! It will impact us all. It will determine the quality of family, relationship, and citizens we will have in the near and long term future. And just like marijuana, it is addictive. It will dupe the general population. Don't fall for it.

Let's think of more rational, creative, and truly progressive solutions.

— Sir Redentor dela Rosa

text:
Passing a law which aims to destroy the sanctity of marriage renders it to a mere "term", a symbol that is meaningless and senseless. It will give the impression that couples entering marriage will also face uncertainties. Today you are married, tomorrow you will be completes trangers. 

If the argument is all about "imposing other's beliefs on others" would it be not ridiculous and ironic on their part to say that passing a law is an exact example of it?

The argument that is now being used by a lot of pro-divorce supporters, including well educated lawmakers is this: "If you don't want divorce, then don't get one". This is silly, illogical and impractical. Divorce when passed as a law will affect all people in the country. It will have a great impact to the society and not just some or selective parties. You cannot just leave an opinion saying: do not do it, let others do it. This is completely ignoring the after effects of divorce. It is in comparable to saying: "If you don't want illegal drugs, then don't get one, but let others who need it have it." It may sounds fallacious but not everything fallacious is necessarily wrong. We are just giving a same scenario to let them understand their point. Studies shows that many countries with absolute divorce, for example in America, increased in the numbers of unending toxic, cycle of divorce.  A divorced man or woman cannot guarantee a happy, good and satisfying second chance and remarriage. Instead, it will just create more broken families and marriages. This is a reality in countries with divorce such as the US and it can also happen in our country. Aside from that, we have many existing legal remedies for domestic violence and all abuses caused by what they call "dysfunctional marrriages". We have legal separation and annullment. We can make it more affordable and accessible instead of divorce. We also have laws about the protection of women and children against violence(VAWC) or RA 9262, an abusive husband can be sued. Similarly, we can also strengthen penalties for domestic violence, infidelity such as concubinage and adultery. No need for a divorce. 

#junkdivorcebillnow

postTitle:
"Divorce is a passport to Hell."

St. Padre Pio
text:
DIVORCE, WHY NOT? 

People who say no to divorce are not imposing their beliefs. That's too obvious to need to be pointed out. What they're saying is that divorce is not for our common good. In fact, it will lead to disaster. It will hurt us more, hurt more children and women, destroy more families, weaken and make relationships and trust more difficult. 

The divorce issue is not just about "if you don't want divorce, then don't get one." Divorce poisons everything and so affects us all. It will make our morally decadent country worse. It will lead to more fatherless children, single moms, and angry, hateful, and suicidal teens. It will just empower and free your husband to enjoy more women in uncommitted relationships. Go research the facts. 

Children can recover easier when their father dies or is jailed. But it will be very difficult for them to recover if they know their divorced father is out there enjoying his free life with other women while they are suffering and experiencing economic difficulties. Thus, the argument on "abusive or nambabae na asawa" is amazing in its irrelevance. We have annulment, legal separation, and enhanced laws on violence committed against women and children. It is the duty of the woman to protect herself and her children from anyone who physically hurts them, even if it is her husband. If a husband is abusive or unfaithful, then jail him. By the way, many dysfunctional relationships today can be resolved by annulments since, truth be told, many marriages today are invalid for obvious reasons.

If two of the grounds for divorce are "abuse" and "unfaithfulness," and if that can be established before the court, then why not jail the perpetrator instead of granting divorce? If the compelling argument is to free the woman and children from the abuse, then the application of existing laws suffice, right? You might object in this way: "But if I jail my husband, who will support us?" But do you really think that if you divorce your husband, you can get a better one? The odds of not getting a new male partner to financially support you and your children after divorce and separation are, in fact, almost the same. Here in the Philippines, for cultural and economic reasons, single moms find it difficult to get financial support from the father of their kids. There is no reason to think that it will improve if we legalize divorce. But there are many reasons to believe it will worsen especially for poor families.

There are practical ways we can do to help problematic families if we are really serious about it. And the truth is, we haven't really gotten serious about it. On the other hand, legalizing divorce is both like and worse than legalizing marijuana or gun ownership. It's not simply giving an option to those who need it while the rest go on with their lives unharmed. No! It will impact us all. It will determine the quality of family, relationship, and citizens we will have in the near and long term future. And just like marijuana, it is addictive. It will dupe the general population. Don't fall for it.

Let's think of more rational, creative, and truly progressive solutions.

— Sir Redentor dela Rosa

postTitle:
"Divorce is a passport to Hell."

St. Padre Pio
text:
Crowley Maddock DIVORCE, WHY NOT? 

People who say no to divorce are not imposing their beliefs. That's too obvious to need to be pointed out. What they're saying is that divorce is not for our common good. In fact, it will lead to disaster. It will hurt us more, hurt more children and women, destroy more families, weaken and make relationships and trust more difficult. 

The divorce issue is not just about "if you don't want divorce, then don't get one." Divorce poisons everything and so affects us all. It will make our morally decadent country worse. It will lead to more fatherless children, single moms, and angry, hateful, and suicidal teens. It will just empower and free your husband to enjoy more women in uncommitted relationships. Go research the facts. 

Children can recover easier when their father dies or is jailed. But it will be very difficult for them to recover if they know their divorced father is out there enjoying his free life with other women while they are suffering and experiencing economic difficulties. Thus, the argument on "abusive or nambabae na asawa" is amazing in its irrelevance. We have annulment, legal separation, and enhanced laws on violence committed against women and children. It is the duty of the woman to protect herself and her children from anyone who physically hurts them, even if it is her husband. If a husband is abusive or unfaithful, then jail him. By the way, many dysfunctional relationships today can be resolved by annulments since, truth be told, many marriages today are invalid for obvious reasons.

If two of the grounds for divorce are "abuse" and "unfaithfulness," and if that can be established before the court, then why not jail the perpetrator instead of granting divorce? If the compelling argument is to free the woman and children from the abuse, then the application of existing laws suffice, right? You might object in this way: "But if I jail my husband, who will support us?" But do you really think that if you divorce your husband, you can get a better one? The odds of not getting a new male partner to financially support you and your children after divorce and separation are, in fact, almost the same. Here in the Philippines, for cultural and economic reasons, single moms find it difficult to get financial support from the father of their kids. There is no reason to think that it will improve if we legalize divorce. But there are many reasons to believe it will worsen especially for poor families.

There are practical ways we can do to help problematic families if we are really serious about it. And the truth is, we haven't really gotten serious about it. On the other hand, legalizing divorce is both like and worse than legalizing marijuana or gun ownership. It's not simply giving an option to those who need it while the rest go on with their lives unharmed. No! It will impact us all. It will determine the quality of family, relationship, and citizens we will have in the near and long term future. And just like marijuana, it is addictive. It will dupe the general population. Don't fall for it.

Let's think of more rational, creative, and truly progressive solutions.

— Sir Redentor dela Rosa

But it will be very difficult for them to recover if they know their divorced father is out there enjoying his free life with other women while they are suffering and experiencing economic difficulties. Thus, the argument on "abusive or nambabae na asawa" is amazing in its irrelevance. We have annulment, legal separation, and enhanced laws on violence committed against women and children. It is the duty of the woman to protect herself and her children from anyone who physically hurts them, even if it is her husband. If a husband is abusive or unfaithful, then jail him. By the way, many dysfunctional relationships today can be resolved by annulments since, truth be told, many marriages today are invalid for obvious reasons.

If two of the grounds for divorce are "abuse" and "unfaithfulness," and if that can be established before the court, then why not jail the perpetrator instead of granting divorce? If the compelling argument is to free the woman and children from the abuse, then the application of existing laws suffice, right? You might object in this way: "But if I jail my husband, who will support us?" But do you really think that if you divorce your husband, you can get a better one? The odds of not getting a new male partner to financially support you and your children after divorce and separation are, in fact, almost the same. Here in the Philippines, for cultural and economic reasons, single moms find it difficult to get financial support from the father of their kids. There is no reason to think that it will improve if we legalize divorce. But there are many reasons to believe it will worsen especially for poor families.

There are practical ways we can do to help problematic families if we are really serious about it. And the truth is, we haven't really gotten serious about it. On the other hand, legalizing divorce is both like and worse than legalizing marijuana or gun ownership. It's not simply giving an option to those who need it while the rest go on with their lives unharmed. No! It will impact us all. It will determine the quality of family, relationship, and citizens we will have in the near and long term future. And just like marijuana, it is addictive. It will dupe the general population. Don't fall for it.

Let's think of more rational, creative, and truly progressive solutions.

— Sir Redentor dela Rosa

You might object in this way: "But if I jail my husband, who will support us?" But do you really think that if you divorce your husband, you can get a better one? The odds of not getting a new male partner to financially support you and your children after divorce and separation are, in fact, almost the same. Here in the Philippines, for cultural and economic reasons, single moms find it difficult to get financial support from the father of their kids. There is no reason to think that it will improve if we legalize divorce. But there are many reasons to believe it will worsen especially for poor families.

There are practical ways we can do to help problematic families if we are really serious about it. And the truth is, we haven't really gotten serious about it. On the other hand, legalizing divorce is both like and worse than legalizing marijuana or gun ownership. It's not simply giving an option to those who need it while the rest go on with their lives unharmed. No! It will impact us all. It will determine the quality of family, relationship, and citizens we will have in the near and long term future. And just like marijuana, it is addictive. It will dupe the general population. Don't fall for it.

Let's think of more rational, creative, and truly progressive solutions.

— Sir Redentor dela Rosa

postTitle:
"Divorce is a passport to Hell."

St. Padre Pio
text:
Saints throughout Christian history have often expressed strong views on the sanctity and indissolubility of marriage, echoing biblical teachings. Here are some key perspectives from prominent saints:

1. **Saint Augustine**:
   Augustine emphasized the permanence of marriage, reflecting Jesus' teachings. He wrote, "The union of male and female for the purpose of procreation is the natural basis of marriage. This is the divine institution, which binds two spouses in a permanent and indissoluble bond" (On the Good of Marriage, Chapter 7).

2. **Saint Thomas Aquinas**:
   Aquinas argued against divorce on theological and philosophical grounds. He believed that marriage is a sacrament and, as such, cannot be dissolved. He stated, "Since marriage is a sacrament, it signifies the union of Christ and the Church, which is indissoluble. Therefore, the marriage bond is also indissoluble" (Summa Theologica, Supplement, Q. 67, Art. 1).

3. **Saint John Chrysostom**:
   John Chrysostom spoke strongly against divorce and remarriage, insisting on the lifelong commitment of marriage. He preached, "It is not marriage that is an evil, but the indulgence and wantonness of those who use it wrongly. For marriage was devised to be a help to us, not for our ruin" (Homily 19 on First Corinthians).

4. **Saint Ambrose**:
   Ambrose upheld the teaching that marriage is indissoluble, stressing the importance of fidelity and the sacredness of the marital bond. He wrote, "The union of marriage is a great sacrament. Divorce is to be avoided and despised, and marriage is to be kept inviolate" (On Virgins, Book II, Chapter 2).

5. **Saint Paul**:
   Although not a saint in the traditional sense, the Apostle Paul's writings have significantly influenced Christian views on marriage and divorce. In his first letter to the Corinthians, he states, "To the married I give this command (not I, but the Lord): A wife must not separate from her husband. But if she does, she must remain unmarried or else be reconciled to her husband. And a husband must not divorce his wife" (1 Corinthians 7:10-11, NIV).

Overall, the consensus among these saints is that marriage is a sacred, indissoluble union intended by God to be permanent, reflecting the relationship between Christ and the Church. Divorce, therefore, is generally viewed as contrary to God's plan for marriage.

postTitle:
"Divorce is a passport to Hell."

St. Padre Pio
text:
The Bible addresses the topic of divorce in several passages across both the Old and New Testaments. Here are the key verses:

### Old Testament

1. **Deuteronomy 24:1-4 (NIV)**
   "If a man marries a woman who becomes displeasing to him because he finds something indecent about her, and he writes her a certificate of divorce, gives it to her and sends her from his house, and if after she leaves his house she becomes the wife of another man, and her second husband dislikes her and writes her a certificate of divorce, gives it to her and sends her from his house, or if he dies, then her first husband, who divorced her, is not allowed to marry her again after she has been defiled. That would be detestable in the eyes of the Lord. Do not bring sin upon the land the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance."

2. **Malachi 2:16 (NIV)**
   "The man who hates and divorces his wife," says the Lord, the God of Israel, "does violence to the one he should protect," says the Lord Almighty. So be on your guard, and do not be unfaithful."

### New Testament

3. **Matthew 5:31-32 (NIV)**
   "It has been said, 'Anyone who divorces his wife must give her a certificate of divorce.' But I tell you that anyone who divorces his wife, except for sexual immorality, makes her the victim of adultery, and anyone who marries a divorced woman commits adultery."

4. **Matthew 19:3-9 (NIV)**
   "Some Pharisees came to him to test him. They asked, 'Is it lawful for a man to divorce his wife for any and every reason?' 'Haven't you read,' he replied, 'that at the beginning the Creator "made them male and female," and said, "For this reason a man will leave his father and mother and be united to his wife, and the two will become one flesh"? So they are no longer two, but one flesh. Therefore what God has joined together, let no one separate.' 'Why then,' they asked, 'did Moses command that a man give his wife a certificate of divorce and send her away?' Jesus replied, 'Moses permitted you to divorce your wives because your hearts were hard. But it was not this way from the beginning. I tell you that anyone who divorces his wife, except for sexual immorality, and marries another woman commits adultery.'"

5. **Mark 10:2-12 (NIV)**
   "Some Pharisees came and tested him by asking, 'Is it lawful for a man to divorce his wife?' 'What did Moses command you?' he replied. They said, 'Moses permitted a man to write a certificate of divorce and send her away.' 'It was because your hearts were hard that Moses wrote you this law,' Jesus replied. 'But at the beginning of creation God "made them male and female." "For this reason a man will leave his father and mother and be united to his wife, and the two will become one flesh." So they are no longer two, but one flesh. Therefore what God has joined together, let no one separate.' When they were in the house again, the disciples asked Jesus about this. He answered, 'Anyone who divorces his wife and marries another woman commits adultery against her. And if she divorces her husband and marries another man, she commits adultery.'"

6. **Luke 16:18 (NIV)**
   "Anyone who divorces his wife and marries another woman commits adultery, and the man who marries a divorced woman commits adultery."

7. **1 Corinthians 7:10-16 (NIV)**
   "To the married I give this command (not I, but the Lord): A wife must not separate from her husband. But if she does, she must remain unmarried or else be reconciled to her husband. And a husband must not divorce his wife. To the rest I say this (I, not the Lord): If any brother has a wife who is not a believer and she is willing to live with him, he must not divorce her. And if a woman has a husband who is not a believer and he is willing to live with her, she must not divorce him. For the unbelieving husband has been sanctified through his wife, and the unbelieving wife has been sanctified through her believing husband. Otherwise your children would be unclean, but as it is, they are holy. But if the unbeliever leaves, let it be so. The brother or the sister is not bound in such circumstances; God has called us to live in peace. How do you know, wife, whether you will save your husband? Or, how do you know, husband, whether you will save your wife?"

These passages collectively provide the biblical perspective on divorce, emphasizing its gravity, the conditions under which it is permissible, and the importance of marital fidelity.
