Maha L Root Ang "separation between Church and state" wala nagapasabot nga walay katungod ang Simbahan mopadayag sa iyang opinyon mahitungod sa mga isyung politikal tungod kay ang mga tawo sulod niini adunay "right to freedom of speech" matod pa sa Art. 3, Sec. 4 sa 1987 Ph Constitution.

So, unsa may pasabot diay sa "separation bet. Church and state" (Art. 2, Sec. 6 of the 1987 Ph Constitution)?

Duhay pasabot niini:

1) Dili makapanghilabot ang gobyerno sa mga tudlo ug kalihukan sa Simbahan gawas kon aduna nay gilapas nga balaod sama sa pag-abusar o pagtamak sa katungod sa tawo ug uban pang kalapasan nga supak sa katilingbanong kaayo (common good).

2) Walay gahom ang Simbahan sa pagdumala sa gobyerno. Nan, kini nagapasabot nga walay katungod nga manghilabot ang Simbahan sa mga plano ug kalihukan nga pang-gobyerno.

Pangutana: Usa ba ka matang sa pagpanghilabot sa gobyerno ang pagpadayag sa opinyon sa Simbahan mahitungod sa mga politikanhong isyu?

Tubag: DILI.

Kon manghilabot gani, nagapasabot na nga "namugos." Unya, namugos diay ang Simbahan? Wala!

Nagpadayag lang ang Simbahan sa iyang opinyon tungod kay ang pagsangyaw sa ebanghelyo wala mag-exempt sa "political arena."

Si Cristo wala moingon nga, "Lakaw kamo sa tanang kanasuran ug isangyaw ang Maayong Balita gawas kon maghisgot na kini og politika."

Kataw-anan kaayo ang mga trolls nga sigeg hisgot sa "separation bet. Church and State" pero wala man diay kasabot sa tinuod nga kahulugan niini.

One goal of evangelization is to "christianize" the world of politics which is "one of the highest forms of charity (Pope Francis, Evangelii Gaudium)."

Catechism of the Catholic Church #2246 says,

"It is a part of the Church's mission to pass moral judgements even in matters related to politics, whenever the fundamental rights of man or the salvation of souls requires it. The means, the only means, she may use are those which are in accord with the Gospel and the welfare of all men according to the diversity of times and circumstances."

postTitle:

St. Padre Pio
text:
Kaitlyn Gosiaco DIVORCE, WHY NOT? 

People who say no to divorce are not imposing their beliefs. That's too obvious to need to be pointed out. What they're saying is that divorce is not for our common good. In fact, it will lead to disaster. It will hurt us more, hurt more children and women, destroy more families, weaken and make relationships and trust more difficult. 

The divorce issue is not just about "if you don't want divorce, then don't get one." Divorce poisons everything and so affects us all. It will make our morally decadent country worse. It will lead to more fatherless children, single moms, and angry, hateful, and suicidal teens. It will just empower and free your husband to enjoy more women in uncommitted relationships. Go research the facts. 

Children can recover easier when their father dies or is jailed. But it will be very difficult for them to recover if they know their divorced father is out there enjoying his free life with other women while they are suffering and experiencing economic difficulties. Thus, the argument on "abusive or nambabae na asawa" is amazing in its irrelevance. We have annulment, legal separation, and enhanced laws on violence committed against women and children. It is the duty of the woman to protect herself and her children from anyone who physically hurts them, even if it is her husband. If a husband is abusive or unfaithful, then jail him. By the way, many dysfunctional relationships today can be resolved by annulments since, truth be told, many marriages today are invalid for obvious reasons.

If two of the grounds for divorce are "abuse" and "unfaithfulness," and if that can be established before the court, then why not jail the perpetrator instead of granting divorce? If the compelling argument is to free the woman and children from the abuse, then the application of existing laws suffice, right? You might object in this way: "But if I jail my husband, who will support us?" But do you really think that if you divorce your husband, you can get a better one? The odds of not getting a new male partner to financially support you and your children after divorce and separation are, in fact, almost the same. Here in the Philippines, for cultural and economic reasons, single moms find it difficult to get financial support from the father of their kids. There is no reason to think that it will improve if we legalize divorce. But there are many reasons to believe it will worsen especially for poor families.

There are practical ways we can do to help problematic families if we are really serious about it. And the truth is, we haven't really gotten serious about it. On the other hand, legalizing divorce is both like and worse than legalizing marijuana or gun ownership. It's not simply giving an option to those who need it while the rest go on with their lives unharmed. No! It will impact us all. It will determine the quality of family, relationship, and citizens we will have in the near and long term future. And just like marijuana, it is addictive. It will dupe the general population. Don't fall for it.

Let's think of more rational, creative, and truly progressive solutions.

— Sir Redentor dela Rosa

postTitle:
"Divorce is a passport to Hell."

St. Padre Pio
text:
Ivory Shore DIVORCE, WHY NOT? 

People who say no to divorce are not imposing their beliefs. That's too obvious to need to be pointed out. What they're saying is that divorce is not for our common good. In fact, it will lead to disaster. It will hurt us more, hurt more children and women, destroy more families, weaken and make relationships and trust more difficult. 

The divorce issue is not just about "if you don't want divorce, then don't get one." Divorce poisons everything and so affects us all. It will make our morally decadent country worse. It will lead to more fatherless children, single moms, and angry, hateful, and suicidal teens. It will just empower and free your husband to enjoy more women in uncommitted relationships. Go research the facts. 

Children can recover easier when their father dies or is jailed. But it will be very difficult for them to recover if they know their divorced father is out there enjoying his free life with other women while they are suffering and experiencing economic difficulties. Thus, the argument on "abusive or nambabae na asawa" is amazing in its irrelevance. We have annulment, legal separation, and enhanced laws on violence committed against women and children. It is the duty of the woman to protect herself and her children from anyone who physically hurts them, even if it is her husband. If a husband is abusive or unfaithful, then jail him. By the way, many dysfunctional relationships today can be resolved by annulments since, truth be told, many marriages today are invalid for obvious reasons.

If two of the grounds for divorce are "abuse" and "unfaithfulness," and if that can be established before the court, then why not jail the perpetrator instead of granting divorce? If the compelling argument is to free the woman and children from the abuse, then the application of existing laws suffice, right? You might object in this way: "But if I jail my husband, who will support us?" But do you really think that if you divorce your husband, you can get a better one? The odds of not getting a new male partner to financially support you and your children after divorce and separation are, in fact, almost the same. Here in the Philippines, for cultural and economic reasons, single moms find it difficult to get financial support from the father of their kids. There is no reason to think that it will improve if we legalize divorce. But there are many reasons to believe it will worsen especially for poor families.

There are practical ways we can do to help problematic families if we are really serious about it. And the truth is, we haven't really gotten serious about it. On the other hand, legalizing divorce is both like and worse than legalizing marijuana or gun ownership. It's not simply giving an option to those who need it while the rest go on with their lives unharmed. No! It will impact us all. It will determine the quality of family, relationship, and citizens we will have in the near and long term future. And just like marijuana, it is addictive. It will dupe the general population. Don't fall for it.

Let's think of more rational, creative, and truly progressive solutions.

— Sir Redentor dela Rosa

postTitle:

St. Padre Pio
text:
𝐌𝐲 𝐑𝐞𝐚𝐬𝐨𝐧𝐬 𝐅𝐨𝐫 𝐒𝐮𝐩𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐃𝐢𝐯𝐨𝐫𝐜𝐞 𝐁𝐢𝐥𝐥.
 
👉Unhappiness: If the marriage has led to consistent feelings of unhappiness and dissatisfaction, divorce may offer a chance for a fresh start and personal fulfillment.

👉Lack of Communication: When communication breakdowns are persistent and efforts to resolve conflicts prove futile, divorce can provide an opportunity to break free from an unhealthy cycle.

👉Emotional Distance: If there is a significant emotional disconnect between partners, divorce may be a necessary step to prioritize individual well-being and emotional health.

👉Different Goals and Values: Misaligned goals, values, or priorities can create ongoing tension and conflict within a marriage, making divorce a viable option for pursuing separate paths.

👉Abuse or Toxicity: In cases of abuse, whether emotional, physical, or psychological, prioritizing safety and well-being by ending the marriage through divorce is crucial.

👉Infidelity: Betrayal through infidelity can severely damage trust and the foundation of a marriage, leading to irreparable harm and a valid reason for considering divorce.

👉Growth and Independence: Sometimes, personal growth and the pursuit of individual goals require separation from a marriage that no longer supports personal development and autonomy. ♥️⚖️🌹

postTitle:

St. Padre Pio
text:
#StPadrePio,

Divorce is a deeply polarizing topic, often igniting intense debate and starkly divergent views. For some, it’s a cataclysmic rupture of a sacred vow, an irrevocable departure from moral and spiritual commitments that they believe leads to personal and eternal damnation. In the eyes of these individuals, divorce is not merely a legal dissolution but a profound moral failure, a deliberate severing of the divine bond of marriage, casting a shadow that stretches into the afterlife—a "passport to hell."

Conversely, for others, divorce is an emancipatory act, a courageous step towards reclaiming one’s life from the grip of a toxic, abusive, or loveless union. It is seen not as a moral failing, but as a necessary assertion of personal dignity and well-being. To these people, remaining in an oppressive marriage is akin to living in a private hell, and divorce is the gateway to liberation and a new beginning.

This clash of perspectives underscores the intense emotional and ethical stakes involved in the decision to divorce. It reflects a broader conflict between traditional doctrines that prioritize the sanctity of marital vows and contemporary values that champion individual happiness and self-fulfillment. Whether seen as a descent into moral chaos or a brave leap towards personal salvation, divorce remains one of the most contentious and profoundly human experiences, laden with profound implications and deep emotional resonance

Period.

St. Padre Pio
text: Para nko dili divorce ang sulbad sa pamilyang nang bikil. Labinag naanay mga anak common na ang problima nga bana o asawa nag binoang nangabot, nangolata nag bisyo nag druga. Looy kaayo ang asawa o bana. Pero unsa may panumpa nato sa ginoo atubangan sa mga katawhan nga ning saksi sa adlaw s kasal nato? Atung hinomdoman sa atung kaminyoon gogma ang pakadak an labina ug naanatay mga anak. Ug naalangtay pag antos inobanan sa gugma. Dili jud divorce ang sulbad sa pamilyang nagka disgosto walang ninyo makita unsa ka looy ang mga anak kon ang ginikan mag bolag. Para nko pag ampo kanunay inobanan ugsakripisyo..simba bisan matg domenggo ug motoo langta ug naay ginoo naajuy kasalbaran ang mga problima. NO To DIVORCE 🙏

text: Yes, kung hindi susundin ang ayon sa Bible,,,kung hindi kayo 99%man lang sa sarili na kayang panindigan ang promise sa kasalan at kayang mag adjust sa isat isa, e bakit pa kayo magpapakasal useless yan,,,kc kung pinili mo xa,taz palpak ,e sino namang kasal anan yon, at kamalian , di sa inyo rin diba? kaya isinubo mo lunokin mo, hanggang kamatayan ,kc yon ang sinabi sa kasalan hanggang libingan, kung di ka 100%, whag kang magpapakasal muna, at mabuti rin whag kayong mag aanak muna pigilan mo sarili mo, whag mong patulan o pagsamantahan ang pagkakataon na marupok xa, kung nhdi mo kaya hanggang kamatayan sa piling niya, kc ang ugali ng bawat tao may pagka masama  at may ron yang mabuting kalouban khit ano pa yan ka sama!, it's depend ,o dependi yan sa pag adjust, kc walang ibang ma sisisi sa mali o kakulangan sa isat isa, ikaw rin o sya, kaya sa tuwing negatibo xa magpositibo ka or birahin mo xa ,hindi dagdagan mo or e push mo pa,,, kung ganon,payo ko sa inyo ,whag na kayong magsimula kung hndi nyo mn lang kaya panindigan o tapusin, kc  lahat na yan mkukuh: by prayer🙏,  walang imposible sa power of God, kadalasan yon, kulang sa pray, pananalig at kulang sa tiis, para sa akin,  ok lang ako mag isa magtitiis  kysa sa  mayrong anak,  mga bata na magdurosa🥲😭, but God is good all the time khit hindi perfect ang buhay natin,but kung buo pananalig ntin, khit mn lang buo ang pamilya nman🙏kaya pagkakayanin,kc tutuong walang imposible ngayon at sa darating pa,aasa pa rin tayo palagi, importanti ang HOPE, PARA REMAIN STANDING🙏🙏🙏SHARE LANG ,BuT the last decision is Ur's ☺️🥰tnx

text:
𝖬𝖺𝗍𝖾𝗈 𝟣𝟫:𝟩-𝟫 (𝖳𝖫𝖠𝖡)

⁷ 𝖲𝗂𝗇𝖺𝖻𝗂 𝗇𝗂𝗅𝖺 𝗌𝖺 𝗄𝖺𝗇𝗂𝗒𝖺, 𝖡𝖺𝗄𝗂𝗍 𝗇𝗀𝖺 𝗶𝗽𝗶𝗻𝗮𝗴𝘂𝘁𝗼𝘀 𝗇𝗂 𝗠𝗼𝗶𝘀𝗲𝘀 𝗇𝖺 𝗺𝗮𝗴𝗯𝗶𝗴𝗮𝘆 𝗇𝗀 𝗸𝗮𝘀𝘂𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗻 𝗌𝖺 𝗽𝗮𝗴𝗵𝗶𝗵𝗶𝘄𝗮𝗹𝗮𝘆, 𝖺𝗍 𝗶𝗵𝗶𝘄𝗮𝗹𝗮𝘆 𝖺𝗇𝗀 𝖻𝖺𝖻𝖺𝖾? 

⁸ 𝖲𝗂𝗇𝖺𝖻𝗂 𝗇𝗂𝗒𝖺 𝗌𝖺 𝗄𝖺𝗇𝗂𝗅𝖺, 𝗗𝗮𝗵𝗶𝗹 𝗌𝖺 𝗸𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗴𝗮𝘀𝗮𝗻 𝗇𝗀 𝗂𝗇𝗒𝗈𝗇𝗀 𝗽𝘂𝘀𝗼 𝖺𝗒 𝗶𝗽𝗶𝗻𝗮𝘂𝗯𝗮𝘆𝗮 𝗌𝖺 𝗂𝗇𝗒𝗈 𝗇𝗂 𝗠𝗼𝗶𝘀𝗲𝘀 𝗇𝖺 𝗂𝗇𝗒𝗈𝗇𝗀 𝗵𝗶𝘄𝗮𝗹𝗮𝘆𝗮𝗻 𝖺𝗇𝗀 𝗂𝗇𝗒𝗈𝗇𝗀 𝗆𝗀𝖺 𝖺𝗌𝖺𝗐𝖺: 𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗽𝘂𝘄𝗮'𝘁 𝗯𝘂𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗌𝖺 𝗽𝗮𝘀𝗶𝗺𝘂𝗹𝗮 𝖺𝗒 𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶 𝗴𝗮𝘆𝗼𝗻. 

⬆ 𝙈𝙖𝙮 "𝙙𝙞𝙫𝙤𝙧𝙘𝙚" 𝘬𝘢𝘺 𝘔𝘰𝘪𝘴𝘦𝘴 𝘯𝘰𝘰𝘯.

𝘗𝘦𝘳𝘰 𝙢𝙚𝙧𝙤𝙣 𝙥𝙖 𝙧𝙞𝙣 𝘬𝘢𝘺 𝙆𝙧𝙞𝙨𝙩𝙤.

𝘉𝘢𝘴𝘵𝘢 𝘢𝘯𝘨 𝙙𝙖𝙝𝙞𝙡𝙖𝙣 𝘯𝘨 "𝙙𝙞𝙫𝙤𝙧𝙘𝙚" 𝘢𝘺 𝙣𝙖𝙠𝙞𝙖𝙥𝙞𝙙 𝘰 𝙣𝙖𝙣𝙜𝙖𝙡𝙪𝙣𝙮𝙖 𝘢𝘯𝘨 𝙖𝙨𝙖𝙬𝙖. ⬇

⁹ 𝖠𝗍 𝗌𝗂𝗇𝖺𝗌𝖺𝖻𝗂 𝗄𝗈 𝗌𝖺 𝗂𝗇𝗒𝗈, 𝖲𝗂𝗇𝗈𝗆𝖺𝗇𝗀 𝗶𝗵𝗶𝘄𝗮𝗹𝗮𝘆 𝖺𝗇𝗀 𝗄𝖺𝗇𝗂𝗒𝖺𝗇𝗀 𝗮𝘀𝗮𝘄𝗮𝗻𝗴 𝖻𝖺𝖻𝖺𝖾, 𝗹𝗶𝗯𝗮𝗻 𝗇𝖺 𝗄𝗎𝗇𝗀 𝗌𝖺 𝗽𝗮𝗸𝗶𝗸𝗶𝗮𝗽𝗶𝗱, 𝖺𝗍 𝗆𝖺𝗀𝖺𝗌𝖺𝗐𝖺 𝗌𝖺 𝗂𝖻𝖺, 𝖺𝗒 𝗇𝖺𝗀𝗄𝖺𝗄𝖺𝗌𝖺𝗅𝖺 𝗇𝗀 𝗉𝖺𝗇𝗀𝖺𝗇𝗀𝖺𝗅𝗎𝗇𝗒𝖺: 𝖺𝗍 𝖺𝗇𝗀 𝗆𝖺𝗀𝖺𝗌𝖺𝗐𝖺 𝗌𝖺 𝖻𝖺𝖻𝖺𝗂𝗇𝗀 𝗒𝖺𝗈𝗇 𝗇𝖺 𝗁𝗂𝗇𝗂𝗐𝖺𝗅𝖺𝗒𝖺𝗇 𝖺𝗒 𝗇𝖺𝗀𝗄𝖺𝗄𝖺𝗌𝖺𝗅𝖺 𝗇𝗀 𝗉𝖺𝗇𝗀𝖺𝗇𝗀𝖺𝗅𝗎𝗇𝗒𝖺.

St. Padre Pio
text: Sorry, Lara Melissa, pero parang gaslighting na po yang pinagsasabi mo! Parang wala ka talagang alam sa aral at turo ng Simbahang Katoliko na nagbabawal sa Divorce dahil yun ang nagdudulot ng malaking problema sa lipunan, pero yung iilan lang sa kanila ang sumusuway kasi kaming mga Katoliko ay may kanya-kanyang pamumuhay at may iilan lang sa kanila ang matitigas ang ulo at meron din sa kanila ang matino at sumusunod, at isa pa, hindi kami gaya niyo mga Born Again na ubod ng ka-ipokritohan! Lagi nga kayo nagbabasa ng Bibliya at mine-memorize niyo ng mga verses, pero hindi niyo nga i-apply sa sarili niyo! Sorry for my words, pero masakit talaga pag nasasaktan! Divorce ang pinag-uusapan natin, hindi yung ibang topic na rebulto dahil matagal nang gasgas yang ganyang argumentong yan! Can you allow me to educate you? Salamat! Yung divorce, imbes na magbigay ng solusyon sa mag-asawa, ay magdulot ng paglala sa problema ng mag-asawa, at pwedeng maapektuhan, magiging kawawa, at makakaranas ng matinding trauma ang mga bata dahil diyan sa divorce na yan! That divorce produces broken families, dahil wala ang Diyos sa puso nila!

postTitle:

St. Padre Pio
text:
Yes!! to divorce bisan pa katoliko ako.

Bisan wara pay divorce sa pinas an problema sa kaminyuon gasanggolit na daan. Bisan pa dili ma-approve ang divorce padayon magkadamo an kaso nan problema sa kaminyuon. Padayon ba sab nato na pasagdan da lamang? 
Nanga divorce an kahadlokan na dili sa amoy hinungdan? Nangasa sa lain mga nasud may divorce mas hapsay pasa hinuon kaysa pinas. 

Kun tinuod gayod nga matinud-anon ug naghinigugmaay  ang magtiayon sa ila kaminyuon, nanga mahadlok man nan divorce?? 

Kun may divorce, samot na mag-ignay kami na mga bana na gapangga nan pamilya na dili makabuhat nan ground sa divorce. Samot na magtadong kami  basin masayop kami, kay basin e-divorce kami nan pinangga namo na asawa. 

Kun walay divorve, kami na pasaway na mga  bana magsalig kami  kay dili man gihapon kami ma-divorce nan amo asawa. Dili sila makawala bisan pa segi kami nan pasagda ug pasagad nan amo oblegasyon sa pamilya kay dili man sila maka-file nan divorce sa amo.  Mag-antos dakan intawon an asawa kay dili man siya poydi mag-asawa utro kay pwedi man siya mapreso kun magminyo siya utro.

Nanga gitugot nan ato balaod ipapreso an bana nan asawa pero dili pwedi e-divorce? 

Nanga gitugot an annulment nanga dili an divorce?

Kun tinuod na gaprotektar kita nan pamilya nanga Gitugot nan balaod ta ba epapreso nan asawa an bana bisan  sa kaso na rape ug uban pa? Mabungkag gihapon kay ipapreso man an padre de pamilya. Kun e-divorce dakan baya kaysa epapreso pa.  

Bisan grabi na ka-toxic an panag-iban segi lang gihapon bahala mosangko sa binun-ogay ug pinatyanay kay no to divorce kita kay amo laong ni father? 😁✌️

Dili tanan kaminyoun gihiusa sa Diyos.

Way pugsanay kun dili na gayod magwork an kaminyuon. Bisan gani an Ginoo gahatag nan kanato nan kagawasan. 

Wag O.A.... YES to divorce....!!!

postTitle:
"Divorce is a passport to Hell."

St. Padre Pio
text:
For those ignorant Pro-Divorce folks who know nothing about the negative consequences of allowing Divorce, here are just 8 out of many detrimental effects that Divorce can have in families and the society in general:

1. Impact on Children’s Well-being:

Numerous studies indicate that children from divorced families often face emotional, psychological, and academic challenges. Research shows that children of divorced parents are more likely to experience anxiety, depression, and behavioral issues. These children also tend to perform worse in school and have lower rates of high school graduation and college attendance compared to their peers from intact families.

Source: Amato, P. R. (2001). "Children of Divorce in the 1990s: An Update of the Amato and Keith (1991) Meta-Analysis."

2. Economic Consequences:

Divorce can have significant financial repercussions for both individuals and society. A study by the Institute for Family Studies reveals that divorced individuals often face a lower standard of living and higher rates of poverty. The financial strain of maintaining two separate households instead of one can lead to increased reliance on public assistance programs, thereby imposing a greater burden on social welfare systems.

Source: Smock, P. J., Manning, W. D., & Gupta, S. (1999). "The Effect of Marriage and Divorce on Women’s Economic Well-Being."

3. Social Stability:

Stable marriages contribute to the overall stability of society. Research published in the Journal of Marriage and Family indicates that communities with higher rates of stable marriages tend to have lower crime rates, better school performance, and stronger social networks. The dissolution of marriages can weaken these communal bonds, leading to broader societal issues.

Source: Amato, P. R. (2000). "The Consequences of Divorce for Adults and Children."

4. Health Impacts:

Divorce is associated with adverse health outcomes for the individuals involved. Studies published in Social Science & Medicine have found that divorced individuals are at higher risk for chronic conditions such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and even early mortality. The stress and emotional toll of divorce can lead to unhealthy coping mechanisms, such as substance abuse, further exacerbating health issues.

Source: Sbarra, D. A., & Nietert, P. J. (2009). "Divorce and Health: Current Trends and Future Directions." 

5. Intergenerational Effects:

Divorce not only affects the immediate family but also has long-term repercussions for future generations. Research from the National Marriage Project indicates that children of divorced parents are more likely to experience divorce themselves as adults. This cycle perpetuates the negative effects of divorce, creating a repeating pattern of family instability and its associated problems.

Source: Wolfinger, N. H. (2005). "Understanding the Divorce Cycle: The Children of Divorce in Their Own Marriages." 

6. Psychological Effects on Adults:

The emotional toll of divorce extends beyond children to the adults involved. According to the Journal of Family Psychology, divorced individuals are more likely to experience significant psychological distress, including feelings of loneliness, depression, and a decrease in life satisfaction. This emotional burden can hinder personal growth and the ability to form stable relationships in the future.

Source: Amato, P. R. (2000). "The Consequences of Divorce for Adults and Children."

7. Workplace Productivity:

Divorce can negatively impact workplace productivity. Studies cited by the American Management Association suggest that employees going through a divorce are more likely to experience decreased productivity, increased absenteeism, and difficulty concentrating at work. This can lead to broader economic consequences for businesses and the economy as a whole.

Source: "How Divorce Affects Productivity in the Workplace," Jones Divorce Law

Magnussen, M. "Minimising the impact of separation and divorce in the workplace," HR Magazine.

8. Costs to the Legal System:

The legal process of divorce is not only costly for the individuals involved but also for the legal system. The expenses associated with court proceedings, legal fees, and administrative costs can be substantial. This financial burden on the legal system can divert resources away from other important areas of public service.

Source: Scafidi, B. (2008). "The Taxpayer Costs of Divorce and Unwed Childbearing: First-Ever Estimates for the Nation and All Fifty States." Institute for American Values.

text:
LaRue Addie I'm not the one whose Review of Related Literature barely reaches 19 sources and yet I am the one failing my thesis? This is actually more of a debate than a thesis defense wherein your evidence to back up your "Pro-Divorce" stance is so little that it barely refutes the 19 new pieces of evidence I gave to prove that divorce has more negative consequences than positive ones. Let me share some of that evidence once again:  

Here are some recent findings from various studies that highlight the negative effects of divorce:

**On Children:**
- A study published in Social Indicators Research found that parental divorce and temporary separation can have significant negative effects on children's cognitive abilities and psychological well-being⁷.
- Another study published in BMC Public Health found that parental separation is associated with mental health problems in adolescence⁸.
- A report in Psychology Today noted that parental divorce is associated with significant risks for children and adolescents, including substance abuse, mental and physical health problems, and poor educational outcomes[^10^].

**On Adults:**
- A study in Frontiers in Psychology found that the mental and physical health of recent divorcees was worse than that of the background population and that higher levels of conflict predicted worse mental health³.
- Another study found that women's median income for the year of their separation or divorce dropped by about 30%, whereas men's median income decreased by only 6%⁹.

**On Society:**
- A study published in Frontiers in Psychology found that divorcees report poorer physical and mental health and more symptoms of stress, anxiety, depression, and social isolation than the general population¹.
- A report published by IDOSR noted that divorce damages society as it consumes social and human capital and diminishes children's future competence in all five of society's major tasks or institutions: family, school, religion, marketplace, and government².

**On Economy:**
- A report in Forbes noted that the average cost of a divorce is $15,000 per person and can increase to $100,000 for a more complicated situation, such as a custody dispute¹¹.
- A study published in SpringerLink found that women are economically disadvantaged following a divorce. Men tend to lose little or no income after a divorce, while the financial losses for women can be substantial⁵.

These findings suggest that divorce can have more negative effects than positive ones on children, adults, society, and the economy. It's also worth noting that many factors can mitigate these effects, such as the quality of the relationship between the divorced parents, the level of conflict during the divorce, and the support systems available to the individuals involved.

LaRue Addie God hates divorce for your information, you're only showing your ignorance on both secular and biblical facts about divorce. You shouldn't talk about things you barely know of:

1. **Malachi 2:16**: "For I hate divorce," says the LORD, the God of Israel. "He who divorces his wife covers his garment with violence," says the LORD of Hosts. So guard yourselves in your spirit and do not break faith².

2. **Matthew 5:31-32**: "It has been said, ‘Anyone who divorces his wife must give her a certificate of divorce.’ But I tell you that anyone who divorces his wife, except for sexual immorality, makes her the victim of adultery, and anyone who marries a divorced woman commits adultery¹.

3. **Mark 10:2-12**: "Some Pharisees came and tested him by asking, “Is it lawful for a man to divorce his wife?” “What did Moses command you?” he replied. They said, “Moses permitted a man to write a certificate of divorce and send her away.” “It was because your hearts were hard that Moses wrote you this law,” Jesus replied. “But at the beginning of creation God ‘made them male and female.’ ‘For this reason a man will leave his father and mother and be united to his wife, and the two will become one flesh.’ So they are no longer two, but one flesh. Therefore what God has joined together, let no one separate.” When they were in the house again, the disciples asked Jesus about this. He answered, “Anyone who divorces his wife and marries another woman commits adultery against her. And if she divorces her husband and marries another man, she commits adultery¹.

4. **Luke 16:18**: "Anyone who divorces his wife and marries another woman commits adultery, and the man who marries a divorced woman commits adultery¹.

5. **1 Corinthians 7:10-16**: "To the rest I say this (I, not the Lord): If any brother has a wife who is not a believer and she is willing to live with him, he must not divorce her. And if a woman has a husband who is not a believer and he is willing to live with her, she must not divorce him. For the unbelieving husband has been sanctified through his wife, and the unbelieving wife has been sanctified through her believing husband⁵.

These verses show that God values marriage and discourages divorce. However, it's important to note that every situation is unique and these verses should be considered in context. If you're facing a difficult situation, it's always a good idea to seek wise counsel.

Mark Jello Edi ikaw mag interview, may research na nga. Ang dami ko nang sources ibinigay which proves divorce has more negative effects than positive ones tapos sa interview ka lang magfofocus. Ikaw mag interview, walk your talk bat uutasan mo ako na hindi ka nga marunong magbasa ng research. Nagbigay na ako ng links, kahit pa in favor ang results ng interview sa anti-Divorce same parin mindset mo. Napakanonsensical. Di mo nga alam na hindi isa sa most common reasons for divorce ang "domestic abuse or violence". 

Based on contemporary research and studies, the most common reasons for divorce include:

1. **Lack of commitment**¹²: This is often cited as the most common reason for divorce. A diminished desire to put effort into making the relationship work can manifest as poor communication, lack of compromise, or the absence of everyday kindness¹.

2. **Constant arguing or conflict**¹²: Constant fighting can signify that a couple is not compatible or have irreconcilable differences¹.

3. **Infidelity**¹²: Extramarital affairs can be a major cause of divorce. For some, infidelity is the main reason their marriage ended, and for others, infidelity is something that happened at the end of years of other problems, such as nasty conflicts, incompatibility, and substance abuse².

4. **Marrying too young**¹²: Marrying at a young age can lead to incompatibility as people often do not know themselves or what they expect and desire in a mate at a young age².

5. **Financial problems**¹: Financial differences and economic hardship can also lead to divorce¹.

6. **Lack of intimacy**³⁴: A lack of physical and emotional intimacy can strain a marriage and lead to divorce³⁴.

It's important to note that reasons for divorce are complex, and most participants cite multiple causes for the decision¹. Also, the reasons can vary by country, often heavily influenced by cultural beliefs and practices¹.

text:
LaRue Addie Basta talaga ayaw maraming dahilan, halatang halata naman na hindi mo sinearch yan. Hindi naman yan ang only evidence that Divorce has more detrimental effects than positive ones:

Here are some findings from contemporary studies and researches that prove divorce can have more negative effects than positive ones on children, adults, society, and the economy:

**Children**:
- A study published in Scientific American found that children of divorced parents often experience short-term negative effects such as anxiety, anger, shock, and disbelief¹⁴.
- Psychology Today reported that even before marital breakup, children whose parents later divorce exhibit higher levels of anxiety, depression, and antisocial behavior than peers whose parents remain married¹⁵.
- Verywell Family noted that children of divorced parents experience increased psychological problems¹⁸.

**Adults**:
- A study published in the Journal of Men’s Health confirmed that divorced people, both men and women, suffer higher rates of mortality, depression, illness in general, and substance abuse than do married people⁴.
- A study in Frontiers in Psychology found that the mental and physical health of recent divorcees was worse than that of the background population immediately following divorce².

**Society**:
- A study published by the International Digital Organization for Scientific Research suggested that divorce damages society. It consumes social and human capital and diminishes children’s future competence in all five of society’s major tasks or institutions: family, school, religion, marketplace, and government[^10^].
- A report by the Australian Institute of Family Studies found that divorce had negative effects on the equivalised household incomes of women in all of the countries studied⁷.

**Economy**:
- Forbes reported that the average cost of a divorce is $15,000 per person and can increase to $100,000 for a more complicated situation, such as a custody dispute⁹.
- A study published in SpringerLink found that women are economically disadvantaged following a divorce. Men tend to lose little or no income after a divorce, while the financial losses for women can be substantial⁶.

These findings prove that while divorce can have both negative and positive effects, the negative impacts often outweigh the positive ones, especially in the short term.

Vin Gitams Jr.

I can see based on your FB profile that your opposition to divorce is rooted in your Catholic faith. So, let's examine how Roman Catholicism has historically influenced social progress. If you need sources to support them, I can provide them individually.

MEN OF SCIENCE, PHILOSOPHY, LITERATURE AND OTHER GREAT THINKERS TORTURED, KILLED AND CONDEMNED BY THE CATHOLIC CHURCH TO KEEP THEIR IRON AGE BELIEFS

 1. Socrates (469-399 BC) - An Athenian philosopher, Socrates was sentenced to death by consuming poison hemlock. He was charged with impiety (not believing in the gods of the state) and corrupting the youth of Athens through his philosophical methods, which challenged the conventional beliefs of the time.
 2. Giordano Bruno (1548-1600) - An Italian philosopher and astronomer, Bruno was burned at the stake by the Roman Inquisition for his views on the infinity of the universe and the existence of multiple worlds, challenging the Church’s theological doctrines.
 3. Galileo Galilei (1564-1642) - Tried by the Inquisition in 1633 for supporting Copernican heliocentrism, contrary to the Church’s teaching of geocentrism. Galileo was forced to recant and lived under house arrest for the remainder of his life.
 4. Jan Hus (c. 1369-1415) - A Czech priest, philosopher, and early church reformer, burned at the stake for his criticisms of the Church’s leadership and corruption, deemed heretical by the Catholic Church.
 5. Michael Servetus (1511-1553) - Opposed by both Catholic and Protestant authorities, he was executed in Calvin’s Geneva for denying the Trinity and other doctrinal disagreements, after escaping Catholic territories.
 6. William Tyndale (c. 1494-1536) - Executed for heresy after translating the Bible into English, challenging the Church’s authority. His execution was backed by the English crown and the Catholic Church.
 7. Lucilio Vanini (1585-1619) - An Italian philosopher and free thinker, charged with atheism and blasphemy, and burned at the stake by the Catholic Church.
 8. Etienne Dolet (1509-1546) - A French scholar and printer, executed for atheism and blasphemy, including critical writings about the Bible and the Church.
 9. Cesare Cremonini (1550-1631) - Faced opposition from the Church for rejecting Aristotelian philosophy endorsed by the Church and denying the immortality of the soul.
 10. Jerome of Prague (1379-1416) - A close associate of Jan Hus, burned at the stake for heresy at the Council of Constance due to his teachings and reforms.
 11. Bruno Bauer (1809-1882) - His critical examinations of Christian origins and biblical criticisms led to opposition from the Catholic establishment, though more directly from the Protestant Church.
 12. Hypatia (c. 360-415 AD) - A mathematician and philosopher in Alexandria, murdered by a Christian mob due to her influence, pagan beliefs, and involvement in local politics, which conflicted with the religious upheaval of the time.

REPORTS OF SEXUAL ABUSES BY CLERGY

1. The Pennsylvania Grand Jury Report: A 2018 report detailing widespread sexual abuse by clergy in Pennsylvania, USA.
 • Summary: This extensive report, released in 2018, documented the sexual abuse of over 1,000 child victims by more than 300 priests over a span of seven decades. The report provided harrowing details of the abuse, cover-ups by Church officials, and the systemic nature of the crimes. It highlighted the failure of Church leaders to report the abuse to law enforcement and their efforts to shield perpetrators from accountability.
 • Detailed Summary of Abuses:
 • Victims ranged from pre-pubescent to teenage years.
 • Abuses included rape, molestation, and other forms of sexual assault.
 • Church officials often reassigned accused priests to different parishes rather than removing them from ministry.
 • Efforts to intimidate or silence victims and their families were documented.
 • A pervasive culture of secrecy and protection of the Church’s reputation over the welfare of the victims was evident.
 2. The McCarrick Report: A 2020 Vatican report on the misconduct of former Cardinal Theodore McCarrick.
 • Summary: The McCarrick Report, released by the Vatican in 2020, detailed the rise and fall of former Cardinal Theodore McCarrick, who was found to have engaged in decades of sexual misconduct, including with minors and young seminarians. The report examined how McCarrick was able to rise to high ranks within the Church despite allegations and rumors about his behavior.
 • Detailed Summary of Abuses:
 • McCarrick was accused of sexually abusing minors and young adult seminarians.
 • Instances of abuse included inappropriate touching, sharing beds, and coerced sexual acts.
 • The report revealed failures within the Church hierarchy, where warnings and accusations were ignored or inadequately investigated.
 • McCarrick’s influential status and fundraising abilities contributed to the reluctance to act on allegations.
 • The report highlighted the need for improved processes for handling accusations and greater transparency within the Church.
 3. Vatileaks: Refers to the leaks of confidential Vatican documents in 2012 and 2015, revealing corruption and financial scandals within the Vatican.
 • Summary: The Vatileaks scandals involved the unauthorized release of confidential Vatican documents, which exposed corruption, financial mismanagement, and internal power struggles within the Vatican. The leaks were facilitated by individuals within the Vatican and brought to light issues that had long been suspected but not publicly documented.
 • Detailed Summary of Abuses:
 • Financial corruption, including misuse of Church funds and embezzlement.
 • Discrepancies in the handling of donations and charitable funds.
 • Evidence of favoritism and nepotism within Vatican appointments and operations.
 • Internal power struggles and conflicts among high-ranking officials.
 • Attempts to cover up financial irregularities and maintain a facade of transparency.
 4. The Sipe Report: Richard Sipe’s research and reports on sexual abuse within the Catholic Church.
 • Summary: Richard Sipe, a former priest and psychotherapist, conducted extensive research on the sexual behavior of Catholic clergy, focusing on the systemic issues contributing to the abuse crisis. His work exposed the prevalence of sexual abuse, the culture of secrecy, and the failures of Church leadership to address the problem effectively.
 • Detailed Summary of Abuses:
 • Sipe estimated that a significant percentage of priests had engaged in sexual misconduct, including abuse of minors.
 • His research highlighted the struggles with celibacy and how it contributed to unhealthy sexual behaviors.
 • Documentation of abuse cases where victims were silenced or intimidated.
 • Detailed accounts of the psychological impact on victims, emphasizing long-term trauma and the need for support.
 • Advocacy for systemic reforms, including greater transparency, accountability, and reconsideration of celibacy requirements for clergy.

These reports collectively underscore the widespread and systemic nature of abuse within the Catholic Church, the failures of Church leadership to protect victims, and the ongoing need for comprehensive reforms.

TAKING ALL THESE INTO ACCOUNT, MY MIDDLE FINGER GOES TO YOUR CHURCH

postTitle:

St. Padre Pio
text:
Vin Gitams Jr. It is a good thing that you have recognized the rebuttal as coming from an AI, Artificial ‘Intelligence.' It indeed comes from a language model whose responses are derived from all available training data it feeds on, including most of what’s available on the internet—your sources included. This AI can provide an unending list of reliable sources that will negate all the arguments presented by the sources you have provided. In fact, depending on how you prompt it, it can rebut its own argument, as there will always be pros and cons in every complex social issue and those are part of its training data. Even the authors of your 'reliable sources' have their own biases in their research and articles.

But you see, the point is this: Having a Divorce Law doesn’t compel anyone to divorce their spouses. If your marriage or whatever form of partnership works for you, by all means, stay in it. But don’t force the absence of an option on hundreds of thousands of women who need to carry on with their lives after a wrong decision.

The central issue extends beyond the capacities of AI. The existence of a Divorce Law does not mandate divorce; rather, it provides a necessary legal framework that enables individuals, particularly women, to exit marriages that are irretrievably broken, abusive, or fundamentally harmful. The absence of such legislation in the Philippines not only traps many women in unhealthy relationships but also exposes their children to the detrimental effects of domestic instability and conflict.

Continued enforcement of antiquated marital laws can perpetuate cycles of abuse, economic dependency, and psychological harm, affecting successive generations. Thus, modernizing the legal framework to include provisions for divorce is not only a matter of personal liberty but also a crucial step towards advancing societal well-being, aligning legal practices with the realities of contemporary social dynamics, and providing equitable opportunities for all citizens to lead safe, fulfilling lives.

—This response is from a human that has been proofread by AI

St. Padre Pio
text:
She RLyn Kaya pala, hindi mo pala alam ang differences ng tatlo:

Annulment: Declares a marriage null; allows remarriage in the Church because If an annulment is granted, both parties are considered free to marry again in the Church because, in the eyes of the Church, THEIR PREVIOUS MARRIAGE WAS NEVER valid due to lack of consent, psychological incapacity, and situations where one or both parties were not free to marry (e.g., due to a previous valid marriage).

Separation: Permits living apart without ending the marriage; does not allow remarriage because while separated, the couple remains married in the eyes of the Church. They are not free to remarry or enter into new romantic relationships, as the marital bond remains intact. Separation can be warranted in cases of domestic violence, abuse, adultery, or other situations that make cohabitation dangerous or impractical.

Divorce: Ends the marriage legally but not sacramentally; does not allow remarriage in the Church without an annulment because the Catholic Church established by Christ upholds that marriage is indissoluble, as Christ Himself stated, "What God has joined together, let no one separate" (Matthew 19:6). Thus, while civil divorce may address legal and practical matters, it does not annul the sacramental bond.

St. Padre Pio
text:
Raul Miranda Uulitin ko po, hindi po basta basta naaprobahan ang divorce. Kung nagdivorce po ulit sa second or third marriage, then hindi po divorce ang problema. Ang problema ay ang daming tao na hindi marunong ng tamang pagtrato sa asawa. 😭 Kaya po nauulit ang pang-aabuso ay hindi dahil ng divorce, dulot po maling pagpapalaki, trauma, flawed mindset at iba pa. Dagdag pa dito, mahirap na din po kasi after divorce na makipagsocialize sa ibang tao at makahanap ng matinong partner. Pagpatak ng age 30-50, mahirap na talaga makahanap ng partner. Hindi po divorce ang problema.

Also, hindi po tama na sa isang statistic lang kayo nagbe-base. Hindi po pwedeng 'yong data na gusto n'yo lang ang basahin at ipresent n'yo. Kailangan n'yo rin po iconsider ang ibang data kahit ito ay taliwas sa gusto n'yong paniwalaan. 

Ang divorce rates sa US ay bumababa na po simula pa noong 2021. Dating 4.0 rate ay naging 2.4 na lang ngayong 2022. Bukod dito, majority po ng divorce ay dahil sa domestic violence (23.5%) at sa infidelity (20-40%). Hindi po hinihikayat ng divorce na makiapid ang mga tao at magkaroon ng madaming asawa.

St. Padre Pio
text:
Maxell Tandan Your response is awful since it is filled with terrible logical fallacies:

1. Tu Quoque Fallacy (Appeal to Hypocrisy)
This fallacy occurs when you respond to criticism by asserting the critic's failure to act consistently with the criticized principles. In this case, you are arguing that because the Catholic Church has had issues with sexual abuse, it cannot speak on other moral issues like divorce. However, this does not logically invalidate the Church's teachings on divorce.

2. Red Herring Fallacy
Again this fallacy involves diverting attention from the main issue by introducing an irrelevant point. The problem of sexual abuse, while serious and important, is separate from the doctrinal teachings on divorce. Bringing up the abuse scandals distracts from the argument about the Catholic Church's stance on divorce.

3. Ad Hominem Fallacy
An ad hominem fallacy attacks the character or actions of the person or institution making the argument rather than addressing the argument itself. By focusing on the Catholic Church’s past failings, you are attacking the institution instead of engaging with the moral reasoning behind the Church’s teachings on marriage and divorce.

4. Straw Man Fallacy
This fallacy occurs when someone misrepresents an opponent's argument to make it easier to attack. You imply that the  Catholic Church’s stance on divorce is about imposing religious principles on non-Catholics. However, the Church’s teachings are primarily directed at its members and their understanding of sacramental marriage.

So in summary, your points are nothing but logical fallacies from your misconceptions and apparent ignorance about the Catholic Church and what it actually teaches about Marraige and Divorce.

Puro lang naman kasi opinyon at speculation yang pinagsasabi mo. Magresearch din kasi kayo at magbasa, based sa evidence mismo mas marami pang negative impacts ang Divorce kesa positive:

1. **Children**:
    - Mental Health Problems: Conflict between divorced parents can lead to mental health problems in children¹.
    - Increased Anxiety and Depression: Children whose parents divorce exhibit higher levels of anxiety, depression, and antisocial behavior².
    - Behavioral Issues: Children of divorce are more likely to have socio-emotional, academic, and mental health concerns³.
    - Risk of Clinical Depression: Children of divorce are at risk of developing clinical depression⁴.
    - Poor Educational Outcomes: Parental divorce is associated with poor educational outcomes².

2. **Family**:
    - Increased Conflict: Divorce often leads to increased conflict and stress within the family¹⁵.
    - Negative Impact on Relationships: Divorce can strain relationships within the family and create a sense of instability¹⁶.
    - Increased Risk of Abuse: Children whose parents have divorced are increasingly the victims of abuse¹⁶.
    - Fear of Abandonment: Children may experience fear of being abandoned when their divorced or separated parents engage in conflict¹.
    - Emotional Distress: Divorce often brings about feelings of grief, sadness, anger, betrayal, guilt, and shame, which can affect the entire family².

3. **Society**:
    - Increased Social and Human Capital Consumption: Divorce consumes social and human capital and diminishes children’s future competence in major societal tasks or institutions[^10^].
    - Increased Poverty Risk: Divorce increases the risk of poverty, particularly for women with children¹¹.
    - Negative Impact on Children's Social Development: Divorce can hinder children's social development¹².
    - Increased Risk of Substance Abuse: Divorce increases the risk of substance abuse and addictions¹¹.
    - Increased Mental and Physical Health Problems: Divorce increases the risk of various physical and mental health problems¹⁴.

4. **Economy**:
    - Decreased Family Income: The family income of children whose parents divorce and remain divorced for at least six years falls by 40 to 45 percent⁷.
    - Increased Poverty: Divorce breeds poverty, particularly in women with children⁶.
    - Financial Strain: Divorce often brings financial strain and social difficulty².
    - Increased Cost to the Taxpayer: Divorce substantially increases cost to the taxpayer, while diminishing the taxpaying portion of society[^10^].
    - Economic Vulnerability: Women experiencing separation or divorce typically undergo marked declines in family income and in measures of economic well-being that take account of family size⁹.

Here are some evidences that highlight the negative impacts of divorce on families and societies:

1. **Societal Impact**: Divorced people are more likely to endure poverty, unemployment, and financial insecurity¹. High divorce rates have become a danger to social stability and can contribute to a loss of social cohesiveness and trust, leading to increased crime and social instability¹. Children of divorced parents may be more inclined to enter high-risk marriages or shun marriage entirely, disrupting societal peace even further¹.

2. **Impact on Children**: Divorce can have a severe influence on children's development. Those who experienced parental divorce had worse self-esteem, greater rates of depression¹. They may blame themselves for their parent’s divorce, resulting in feelings of regret and guilt¹. The negative impacts of divorce on children extend beyond their emotional well-being, which might harm their intellectual advancement. They may struggle with education and are more likely to drop out¹. They are more likely to get suspended from school, use firearms, and run away from home, which can lead to criminal behavior and teen pregnancies¹.

3. **Family Impact**: Family breakup affects the family’s vital social unit and may negatively impact society’s principles¹. Divorcing parents may engage their children in the process, which can have long-term consequences¹.

These are just a few examples. The effects of divorce are complicated and far-reaching, and while divorce may be inevitable in some cases, it is necessary to recognize and handle the potential effects¹.

Sources:
(1) The Effects of Divorce on Family and Society – Loveable - AVADA. https://avada.io/loveable/blog/the-effects-of-divorce/.
(2) The Effects of Marriage and Divorce on Families and Children. https://www.mdrc.org/work/publications/effects-marriage-and-divorce-families-and-children.
(3) Effects of Divorce on Children: Behavioral, Social, and More - Healthline. https://www.healthline.com/health/parenting/effects-of-divorce-on-children.

Maxell Tandan I'm not ignoring that fact, I was waiting for you to say that so that I can admonish you with evidence of what the Catholic Church has been doing to solve the abuse crisis. 

The Catholic Church has been taking several steps to address the abuse crisis:

1. **Transparency**: A key element in resolving the crisis is transparency. This includes releasing the names of those credibly accused⁴.

2. **The Dallas Charter**: In response to the revelations of abuse, the U.S. bishops adopted the Charter for the Protection of Children and Young People, commonly called the Dallas Charter, in June 2002². The Charter set standards for responding to persons who had been abused, preventing future abuse, holding offenders accountable, and being transparent about allegations and those clerics who had been removed from ministry².

3. **Preventive Measures**: The charter’s programs, such as mandatory screening of candidates for ordination, abuse-awareness training, and the removal of men from ministry who had committed even one act of abuse, were successful in significantly reducing the number of abuse cases².

4. **Papal Efforts**: Pope Francis has made efforts to address the problem, including holding an unprecedented summit on pedophilia in the Church, and changing its laws to explicitly criminalize sexual abuse³.

It's important to note that while these measures have led to a significant reduction in the number of abuse cases, the Catholic Church continues to work on this issue, and it's a complex and ongoing process.

Sources:

The Catholic Church maintains that marriage is a lifelong commitment and does not recognize divorce in the sense of ending a valid marriage before the death of the spouses¹²³. HOWEVER, the Church does recognize that there are situations where a married couple may need to live apart, and civil divorce may be tolerated under certain circumstances¹.

The Catechism of the Catholic Church states that civil divorce may be tolerated if it is the only possible way of ensuring certain legal rights, the care of the children, or the protection of inheritance¹. It's important to note that this does not mean the Church recognizes the marriage as ended. The marriage bond remains, and the parties are not free to remarry in the Church unless an annulment is granted¹³.

In cases of grave circumstances, such as domestic violence or abuse, the Church permits and even encourages separation for the safety of the spouse and children¹³. This is referred to as "separation from bed and board" (divortium imperfectum), and it is allowed for various causes, especially in the case of adultery or lapse into infidelity or heresy on the part of husband or wife³.

It's crucial to consult with a priest or a canon lawyer for guidance in these matters, as each situation is unique and requires careful discernment¹²³.

Source: Conversation with Copilot, 5/30/2024

postTitle:
"Divorce is a passport to Hell."

St. Padre Pio
text:
Romeo Garcia Campanero Ang Diyos lamang ang may alam kung sino ang pupunta sa impyerno at sino ang hindi. We are not against divorce solely because of God but because Divorce itself destroys families, society, and the economy in general. SImple research lang gagawin mo para malaman mo yang mga facts na yan:

Here are some evidences that highlight the negative impacts of divorce on families and societies:

1. **Societal Impact**: Divorced people are more likely to endure poverty, unemployment, and financial insecurity¹. High divorce rates have become a danger to social stability and can contribute to a loss of social cohesiveness and trust, leading to increased crime and social instability¹. Children of divorced parents may be more inclined to enter high-risk marriages or shun marriage entirely, disrupting societal peace even further¹.

2. **Impact on Children**: Divorce can have a severe influence on children's development. Those who experienced parental divorce had worse self-esteem, greater rates of depression¹. They may blame themselves for their parent’s divorce, resulting in feelings of regret and guilt¹. The negative impacts of divorce on children extend beyond their emotional well-being, which might harm their intellectual advancement. They may struggle with education and are more likely to drop out¹. They are more likely to get suspended from school, use firearms, and run away from home, which can lead to criminal behavior and teen pregnancies¹.

3. **Family Impact**: Family breakup affects the family’s vital social unit and may negatively impact society’s principles¹. Divorcing parents may engage their children in the process, which can have long-term consequences¹.

These are just a few examples. The effects of divorce are complicated and far-reaching, and while divorce may be inevitable in some cases, it is necessary to recognize and handle the potential effects¹.

Sources:
(1) The Effects of Divorce on Family and Society – Loveable - AVADA. https://avada.io/loveable/blog/the-effects-of-divorce/.
(2) The Effects of Marriage and Divorce on Families and Children. https://www.mdrc.org/work/publications/effects-marriage-and-divorce-families-and-children.
(3) Effects of Divorce on Children: Behavioral, Social, and More - Healthline. https://www.healthline.com/health/parenting/effects-of-divorce-on-children.

St. Padre Pio
text:
Romeo Garcia Campanero Anti-Divorce kami hindi lamang dahil sa religion namin but also based on facts and logic. Wag mo ding lahatin na porket relihiyoso kami ay hindi na kami marunong magresearch at gumamit ng mga ebidensya. 

Here are some negative effects of divorce based on contemporary studies:

1. **Children**:
    - Mental Health Problems: Conflict between divorced parents can lead to mental health problems in children¹.
    - Increased Anxiety and Depression: Children whose parents divorce exhibit higher levels of anxiety, depression, and antisocial behavior².
    - Behavioral Issues: Children of divorce are more likely to have socio-emotional, academic, and mental health concerns³.
    - Risk of Clinical Depression: Children of divorce are at risk of developing clinical depression⁴.
    - Poor Educational Outcomes: Parental divorce is associated with poor educational outcomes².

2. **Family**:
    - Increased Conflict: Divorce often leads to increased conflict and stress within the family¹⁵.
    - Negative Impact on Relationships: Divorce can strain relationships within the family and create a sense of instability¹⁶.
    - Increased Risk of Abuse: Children whose parents have divorced are increasingly the victims of abuse¹⁶.
    - Fear of Abandonment: Children may experience fear of being abandoned when their divorced or separated parents engage in conflict¹.
    - Emotional Distress: Divorce often brings about feelings of grief, sadness, anger, betrayal, guilt, and shame, which can affect the entire family².

3. **Society**:
    - Increased Social and Human Capital Consumption: Divorce consumes social and human capital and diminishes children’s future competence in major societal tasks or institutions[^10^].
    - Increased Poverty Risk: Divorce increases the risk of poverty, particularly for women with children¹¹.
    - Negative Impact on Children's Social Development: Divorce can hinder children's social development¹².
    - Increased Risk of Substance Abuse: Divorce increases the risk of substance abuse and addictions¹¹.
    - Increased Mental and Physical Health Problems: Divorce increases the risk of various physical and mental health problems¹⁴.

4. **Economy**:
    - Decreased Family Income: The family income of children whose parents divorce and remain divorced for at least six years falls by 40 to 45 percent⁷.
    - Increased Poverty: Divorce breeds poverty, particularly in women with children⁶.
    - Financial Strain: Divorce often brings financial strain and social difficulty².
    - Increased Cost to the Taxpayer: Divorce substantially increases cost to the taxpayer, while diminishing the taxpaying portion of society[^10^].
    - Economic Vulnerability: Women experiencing separation or divorce typically undergo marked declines in family income and in measures of economic well-being that take account of family size⁹.

Source: Conversation with Copilot, 5/29/2024

postTitle:

St. Padre Pio
text:
Lou Baltazar So yung nagreresearch pa yung walang alam ngayon? Matuto kasi dapat kayo magresearch hindi puro tsismis lang sa Social Media ang inaatupag. Majority sa divorce sa buong mundo ay hindi naman dahil sa "domestic violence" kundi sa iba pang rason. Puro kasi kayo pilit ng pilit na divorce ay dapat matupad sa bansa para masolusyonan ang domestic violence sa pamilya pero based on facts and not mere opinions or feelings, ang ebidensya ay kasalungat sa pinagsasabi niyo. Here are just some facts and statistics that refute the argument that the majority of divorces are caused solely by domestic abuse or violence:

1. According to a report by Forbes Advisor, the most common reasons for divorce include lack of commitment (75%), infidelity (59.6%), irreconcilable differences (57.7%), marrying too young (45.1%), financial hardship (36.7%), and substance abuse (34.6%). Domestic violence was listed as a cause in only 23.5% of cases which is the least¹⁸.

2. A study published on Our World in Data also shows that the reasons for divorce are complex and vary greatly across different countries, not merely because of domestic abuse or violence⁷.

3. A report by Sacks and Sacks Law states that approximately only 23.5% out of 100% divorces list domestic abuse as a contributing factor⁵.

4. A study published also on JSTOR suggests that only 25-40 percent out of 100 percent of women are initiating divorce because of domestic abuse⁶.

5. According to the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence, only 1 in 4 women and only 1 in 9 men experience severe intimate partner physical violence, intimate partner contact sexual violence, and/or intimate partner stalking. However, not even all of these cases result in divorce at all².

6. A report by Psychology Today states that concerns about domestic violence may be raised in up to only half of all separation and divorce cases⁴. However, this does not also mean that domestic violence is the sole cause of these divorces.

These statistics clearly show that while domestic violence is a significant issue and does contribute to divorce, it is not the primary cause in the majority of cases because there are many other factors at play, and each case is unique. It's important to consider all these factors when discussing the many causes of divorce instead of focusing solely on domestic violence which isn't even the majority of the reason for divorce.

Sources:
(1) Revealing Divorce Statistics In 2024 – Forbes Advisor. https://www.forbes.com/advisor/legal/divorce/divorce-statistics/.
(2) Divorce Rates in the World [Updated 2024]. https://divorce.com/blog/divorce-rates-in-the-world/.
(3) Marriages and Divorces - Our World in Data. https://ourworldindata.org/marriages-and-divorces.
(4) Top Ten Reasons For Divorce - sacksandsackslaw.com. https://sacksandsackslaw.com/digging-into-the-data-the-top-10-reasons-for-divorce/.
(5) Domestic Violence: The Dark Side of Divorce - JSTOR. https://www.jstor.org/stable/25804911.
(6) Statistics - NCADV. https://ncadv.org/statistics.
(7) Domestic Violence and Divorce: Common Questions and Answers. https://www.psychologytoday.com/intl/blog/5-types-people-who-can-ruin-your-life/202112/domestic-violence-and-divorce-common-questions-and.
(8) 3 Kinds of Divorce Statistics You Can Learn From. https://gabriellehartley.com/3-kinds-of-divorce-statistics-you-can-learn-from/.
(9) Understanding Divorce: Global Trends and Key Statistics. https://www.therapyden.com/blog/divorce-statistics.
(10) Is Divorce On The Rise—And What Factors Are Contributing To It?. https://www.ajs.org/is-divorce-on-the-rise/.

postTitle:
"Divorce is a passport to Hell."

St. Padre Pio
text:
She RLyn Hindi naman majority ng divorce ay nangyayari dahil sa domestic abuse or violence. In fact, contemporary studies indicate that the reasons for divorce are varied and complex, with domestic abuse or violence being only one out of many factors. According to a national survey from 2005, the 12 top reasons for divorce in the United States, from most to least common, are¹:

1. **Lack of commitment**
2. **Constant arguing or conflict**
3. **Infidelity**
4. **Marrying too young**
5. **Unrealistic expectations about partner or marriage**
6. **Inequality between partners**
7. **Inadequate preparation for marriage**
8. **Domestic violence**
9. **Financial problems**
10. **Conflict about domestic work**
11. **Lack of family support**
12. **Religious differences**

As you can see here and on the links, domestic violence is only one of the reasons, but it's not even the most common one at all. The most common reasons for divorce are lack of commitment, constant arguing or conflict, and infidelity¹.

Aside from that, a study published by Oxford Academic provides an update on the current research concerning marital dissolution, including its causes². Wherein it emphasizes that the causes of divorce are complex and most participants cite multiple reasons for the decision² and not merely because of domestic violence or abuse alone.

So overall, while domestic abuse or violence is of course a serious issue and does contribute to divorce, it is not accurate to even say that the majority of divorces happen because of domestic abuse. There are many other factors at play, and each case is unique. It's very important to consider all these factors when discussing the causes of divorce instead of just focusing on domestic violence and abuse which is not even the most common reason for divorce in the first place.

Sources:
(1) Top 12 Reasons for Divorce and Why Marriages Fail - Psych Central. https://psychcentral.com/relationships/top-reasons-for-divorce.
(2) Divorce and Close Relationships: Findings, Themes, and Future .... https://academic.oup.com/edited-volume/38162/chapter/332995775.
(3) Causes Of Divorce: 19 Of The Most Common Reasons. https://divorce.com/blog/causes-of-divorce/.
(4) undefined. https://doi.org/10.1093/oxfordhb/9780195398694.013.0036.

postTitle:

St. Padre Pio
text:
Jose Mari In Matthew 19:3-9, the Pharisees question Jesus about the lawfulness of divorce for any reason. Jesus points back to God's original intent for marriage: "Therefore what God has joined together, let no one separate" (Matthew 19:6). It seems like you don't even understand that the allowance for divorce due to "the hardness of hearts" (Matthew 19:8) was a concession by Moses, not part of God's original design for marriage. In fact, the Greek word used for "sexual immorality" in Matthew 5:32 and 19:9 is "porneia," which can encompass a range of illicit sexual behaviors but is not strictly limited to adultery. Many bible scholars teach that "porneia" in these passages refer specifically to unlawful marriages, such as incestuous relationships, rather than infidelity within a legitimate marriage.

The Bible itself rejects Divorce, for example, Mark 10:11-12 provides a parallel account: "Anyone who divorces his wife and marries another woman commits adultery against her. And if she divorces her husband and marries another man, she commits adultery." Not a single exception clause is even mentioned here. Luke 16:18 also echoes this teaching: "Anyone who divorces his wife and marries another woman commits adultery, and the man who marries a divorced woman commits adultery." Again, no exception clause is given showing that there are no exceptions for Divorce.

Aside from that, the Catholic Church teaches that marriage is a sacrament, reflecting the unbreakable union between Christ and His Church (Ephesians 5:31-32).
The Church upholds the "exception clause" in Matthew as a reference to invalid marriages, not a justification for divorce and remarriage. Therefore, a valid sacramental marriage can never be dissolved in the eyes of God and His Church. This truth is consistent with the biblical teaching that marriage is indissoluble (Catechism of the Catholic Church, 1614-1615). Even our Lord Jesus Christ's teaching restores the original vision of marriage from Genesis 2:24, where a man and woman become "one flesh." By addressing the hardness of human hearts, Jesus our Lord emphasizes the call to fidelity and the grace available to live out this covenantal relationship which divorce contradicts.

1. Impact on Children’s Well-being: While it's true that a conflict-free divorce can be less harmful than a high-conflict marriage, the impact of divorce on children is generally negative. Studies show that children of divorce are more likely to experience social withdrawal, academic struggles, and mental health problems such as anxiety and depression¹¹¹²¹⁴¹⁵.

2. Economic Consequences: Divorce often leads to significant financial challenges. Women, in particular, face substantial financial losses after a divorce¹²⁴⁵⁶. Moreover, the economic instability caused by divorce can lead to increased poverty rates, especially among single parents¹.

3. Social Stability: High divorce rates can contribute to a loss of social cohesiveness and trust, leading to increased social instability²⁵²⁶. 

4. Health Impacts: Divorce is associated with negative health outcomes, including increased risk of chronic health problems such as heart disease and cancer⁷⁹³⁹. 

5. Intergenerational Effects: Children of divorced parents are more likely to experience divorce themselves¹⁷¹⁸¹⁹. This cycle can perpetuate the negative effects of divorce across generations.

6. Psychological Effects on Adults: Divorce can lead to significant psychological distress, including increased stress, lower life satisfaction, depression, and substance abuse⁷⁸⁹.

7. Work Productivity: Divorce can significantly impact work productivity. Studies have found that employee productivity falls by 40% during the first 6 months of divorce²⁸²⁹[^30^]³².

8. Costs to the Legal System: The average cost of a divorce in the U.S. is about $7,000, but this can vary widely. More complicated divorces can cost significantly more, often running up tabs well over $100,000³³³⁴³⁶³⁷³⁸. This imposes a significant financial burden on the individuals involved and the legal system.

text:
Ajax Amurao Annulment and Separation are allowed by the Church to protect the spouse and the children but civil divorce is on a case-to-case basis only:

The Catholic Church maintains that marriage is a lifelong commitment and does not recognize divorce in the sense of ending a valid marriage before the death of the spouses¹²³. However, the Church does recognize that there are situations where a married couple may need to live apart, and civil divorce may be tolerated under certain circumstances¹.

The Catechism of the Catholic Church states that civil divorce may be tolerated if it is the only possible way of ensuring certain legal rights, the care of the children, or the protection of inheritance¹. It's important to note that this does not mean the Church recognizes the marriage as ended. The marriage bond remains, and the parties are not free to remarry in the Church unless an annulment is granted¹³.

In cases of grave circumstances, such as domestic violence or abuse, the Church permits and even encourages separation for the safety of the spouse and children¹³. This is referred to as "separation from bed and board" (divortium imperfectum), and it is allowed for various causes, especially in the case of adultery or lapse into infidelity or heresy on the part of husband or wife³.

St. Padre Pio
text:
Mark Jello Your argument is based on feelings and not on facts. The Church already allows "separation" and "annulment" to protect the spouse and kids. Divorce only allows the abuser in the marriage to remarry again and do the same thing to their future spouse and children like what happened to you. 

Contemporary research has identified several negative impacts of divorce on children:

1. **Emotional Trauma**: Children and their parents can experience emotional trauma before, during, and after a separation or divorce¹. This can lead to behavior changes in the first year of parent separation¹.

2. **Behavioral Issues**: Many children show behavior changes in the first year of parent separation¹. Adjustment to a new living situation, continuing parental tensions, and alienation can cause distress in the child¹.

3. **Psychological Difficulties**: Research shows that children of divorce are more likely to have socio-emotional, academic, and mental health concerns, such as anxiety, stress, depression, insomnia, behavioral issues, challenges in making and keeping friends, and trouble at school⁴.

4. **Increased Anxiety and Depression**: Research published by sociologist Lisa Strohschein showed that, even before marital breakup, children whose parents later divorce exhibit higher levels of anxiety, depression, and antisocial behavior than peers whose parents remain married³.

5. **Long-term Effects**: A comprehensive review of research from several disciplines regarding the effects of divorce on children yields a growing consensus that significant numbers of children suffer for many years from psychological and social difficulties associated with continuing and/or new stresses within the post-divorce family and experience heightened anxiety in forming enduring attachments at later developmental stages including young adulthood⁵.

6. **Negative Impact on Cognitive Abilities and Psychological Well-being**: The dissolution of high-quality parental unions has the most harmful effects on children, especially concerning conduct problems². Parental temporary separation is a type of family disruption that has significant negative effects on young children².

7. **Substance Abuse and Addictions, Mental and Physical Health Problems, and Poor Educational Outcomes**: U.S.-based psychologist Sharlene Wolchik and colleagues found that parental divorce is associated with significant risks for children and adolescents, including substance abuse and addictions, mental and physical health problems, and poor educational outcomes³.

It's important to note that these are general trends and individual experiences can vary greatly. Support from parents, counseling, and other resources can help mitigate some of these effects.

Source:
(1) Helping Children and Families Deal With Divorce and Separation. https://publications.aap.org/pediatrics/article/138/6/e20163020/52651/Helping-Children-and-Families-Deal-With-Divorce.

Red Herring Fallacy occurs when an irrelevant topic or side issue is introduced into the argument, thereby diverting attention from the relevant debate. It’s essentially an attempt to change the subject and divert attention elsewhere1. This tactic is commonly used in debates and political discourse to draw attention away from a difficult point or potential flaws in an argument. It’s important to note that this can lead to unsupported conclusions and can be misleading.

text:
Fatima LA 
 
𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗿𝗲𝗰𝘁? ⬇
  
𝗕𝗨𝗧𝗔𝗧𝗔 𝗦𝗧𝗥𝗜𝗞𝗘 𝟮 ⬇
  
𝖬𝖺𝗍𝖾𝗈 𝟣𝟫:𝟩-𝟫 (𝖳𝖫𝖠𝖡)

⁷ 𝖲𝗂𝗇𝖺𝖻𝗂 𝗇𝗂𝗅𝖺 𝗌𝖺 𝗄𝖺𝗇𝗂𝗒𝖺, 𝖡𝖺𝗄𝗂𝗍 𝗇𝗀𝖺 𝗶𝗽𝗶𝗻𝗮𝗴𝘂𝘁𝗼𝘀 𝗇𝗂 𝗠𝗼𝗶𝘀𝗲𝘀 𝗇𝖺 𝗺𝗮𝗴𝗯𝗶𝗴𝗮𝘆 𝗇𝗀 𝗸𝗮𝘀𝘂𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗻 𝗌𝖺 𝗽𝗮𝗴𝗵𝗶𝗵𝗶𝘄𝗮𝗹𝗮𝘆, 𝖺𝗍 𝗶𝗵𝗶𝘄𝗮𝗹𝗮𝘆 𝖺𝗇𝗀 𝖻𝖺𝖻𝖺𝖾? 

⁸ 𝖲𝗂𝗇𝖺𝖻𝗂 𝗇𝗂𝗒𝖺 𝗌𝖺 𝗄𝖺𝗇𝗂𝗅𝖺, 𝗗𝗮𝗵𝗶𝗹 𝗌𝖺 𝗸𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗴𝗮𝘀𝗮𝗻 𝗇𝗀 𝗂𝗇𝗒𝗈𝗇𝗀 𝗽𝘂𝘀𝗼 𝖺𝗒 𝗶𝗽𝗶𝗻𝗮𝘂𝗯𝗮𝘆𝗮 𝗌𝖺 𝗂𝗇𝗒𝗈 𝗇𝗂 𝗠𝗼𝗶𝘀𝗲𝘀 𝗇𝖺 𝗂𝗇𝗒𝗈𝗇𝗀 𝗵𝗶𝘄𝗮𝗹𝗮𝘆𝗮𝗻 𝖺𝗇𝗀 𝗂𝗇𝗒𝗈𝗇𝗀 𝗆𝗀𝖺 𝖺𝗌𝖺𝗐𝖺: 𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗽𝘂𝘄𝗮'𝘁 𝗯𝘂𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗌𝖺 𝗽𝗮𝘀𝗶𝗺𝘂𝗹𝗮 𝖺𝗒 𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶 𝗴𝗮𝘆𝗼𝗻. 

⬆ 𝙈𝙖𝙮 "𝙙𝙞𝙫𝙤𝙧𝙘𝙚" 𝘬𝘢𝘺 𝘔𝘰𝘪𝘴𝘦𝘴 𝘯𝘰𝘰𝘯.

𝘗𝘦𝘳𝘰 𝙢𝙚𝙧𝙤𝙣 𝙥𝙖 𝙧𝙞𝙣 𝘬𝘢𝘺 𝙆𝙧𝙞𝙨𝙩𝙤.

𝘉𝘢𝘴𝘵𝘢 𝘢𝘯𝘨 𝙙𝙖𝙝𝙞𝙡𝙖𝙣 𝘯𝘨 "𝙙𝙞𝙫𝙤𝙧𝙘𝙚" 𝘢𝘺 𝙣𝙖𝙠𝙞𝙖𝙥𝙞𝙙 𝘰 𝙣𝙖𝙣𝙜𝙖𝙡𝙪𝙣𝙮𝙖 𝘢𝘯𝘨 𝙖𝙨𝙖𝙬𝙖. ⬇

St. Padre Pio
text:
Addressing the concerns about divorce and its impact on families and society requires a nuanced approach. While there are indeed challenges associated with divorce, there are also significant detrimental effects of remaining in a dysfunctional or harmful marriage. Here’s a detailed argument for each point raised against divorce:

 1. Impact on Children’s Well-being:
While it is true that divorce can lead to challenges for children, the impact of staying in a conflically charged or abusive household can be far more detrimental. Studies have shown that children exposed to constant marital conflict experience greater psychological problems than those from divorced families. In environments where parents manage post-divorce parenting cooperatively, children can adjust well and often benefit from relief from chronic household tension.
 2. Economic Consequences:
Economic challenges following divorce are significant, but the alternative—staying in an unhappy marriage—can also lead to economic inefficiency and distress. For instance, individuals in unhappy marriages may experience decreased productivity and motivation, affecting their earning potential. Progressive countries offer social safety nets and support systems like job training for divorced individuals, helping them regain financial stability independently.
 3. Social Stability:
While stable marriages do contribute to societal stability, the quality of the marital relationship is crucial. High-conflict marriages can contribute to community instability more than a well-handled divorce. For example, Scandinavian countries focus on strong community support systems that provide both marital counseling to prevent unnecessary divorces and robust support for those where divorce is the healthier option.
 4. Health Impacts:
Divorce indeed correlates with certain negative health outcomes, but staying in a stressful or abusive marriage can be even more harmful. Chronic stress from bad marriages is linked to severe health issues, including heart disease and mental health disorders. Societies with accessible healthcare and mental health services help mitigate these risks, supporting individuals through and after the divorce process.
 5. Intergenerational Effects:
While children of divorced parents may have a higher propensity to divorce, the modeling of unhealthy relationships in intact but dysfunctional marriages can teach negative relationship patterns as well. Education about healthy relationships and access to counseling can break this cycle, providing tools for better relationship management, which is an approach seen in countries like Canada and Australia.
 6. Psychological Effects on Adults:
The psychological toll of divorce on adults is significant; however, the emotional and psychological damage of remaining in an unhappy or abusive marriage can be far worse. Mental health support and counseling post-divorce can help individuals recover and move forward more healthily than if they had remained in detrimental relationships.
 7. Work  Productivity:
While divorce can affect workplace productivity, the stress of an unhappy marriage also impacts work performance. Employers in many progressive countries offer support like flexible work hours and counseling, which helps maintain productivity and supports employees through personal challenges, including divorce.
 8. Costs to the Legal System:
Divorce does impose costs on the legal system, but these can be mitigated through alternative dispute resolution methods such as mediation and collaborative law, which are less adversarial and costly than traditional divorce proceedings. Many countries are now promoting these methods to reduce the strain on the court system and make the process less financially burdensome for all parties involved.

Jose Mari Pinagsasabi mo, mindset talaga ng sektang ginagamit ang Bibliya out of context at without proper guidance and interpretation. The Bible itself rejects Divorce:

“But I tell you that anyone who divorces his wife, except for sexual immorality, makes her the victim of adultery, and anyone who marries a divorced woman commits adultery.” – Matthew 5:32, NIV

God created marriage as the perfect union between man and woman so they could raise a family. This is a covenant for life; and should not be entered into lightly, with divorce as an option. Divorce in the Bible is only considered under the only exceptional circumstance of sexual immorality.

If either spouse remarries a person not divorced under this rule, or if they have not been divorced because of immoral behavior, then they will have committed adultery. If you are unmarried and marry a man or woman who has not been divorced under the aforementioned rule, you will also have committed adultery.

Magresearch naman kayo tulad nito:

Divorce can significantly impact children's emotional well-being, causing stress, depression, distress, and anxiety. However, not all children experience negative effects, as some can adapt to new living arrangements and thrive. Young children may blame themselves for their parents' divorce, experiencing sadness, anger, and confusion. It is crucial for parents to reassure them that the divorce is not their fault and they are still loved.

Adolescents may experience anger, sadness, resentment, struggle with identity and self-esteem, and may engage in risky behaviors. Parents play a crucial role in helping their children navigate the emotional impact of divorce by maintaining a positive relationship, being available to talk about their feelings, and avoiding negative language about their ex-spouse.

Living arrangements can also impact children's emotional well-being, as they may struggle with the transition of living in two homes and may feel loneliness or isolation. It is essential for parents to create a stable and supportive environment for their children, regardless of their living situation.

https://lisareneewilcox.com/impact-of-divorce-on-children
